Hail and high wind reports were too numerous to mention individually here.  Numerous reports of golf ball size hail were received.  Boone and Story Counties reported some of the largest hail with the event as baseball size hail pelted the are.  There was one report of very large hail northwest of Slater in Story County.  Hail five and one half inches in diameter punched 8 holes through a steel roof.  There was severe house siding and roof damage in the area.  There were numerous tornadoes, especially in the central Iowa Iowa.  At one point there were several supercells around the metropolitan Des Moines area.  Two of the stronger tornadoes touched down west and south of Des Moines.  Fortunately, most of the tornado tracks were over open areas and resulted in little damage.  High winds became a problem, especially after sunset, as the complex from Nebraska moved in.  The system became more of a derecho during the late night hours.  Eighty plus MPH winds pelted southwest Iowa and downed barns and several buildings in Adams and Cass Counties.  A beta bow element formed in central Iowa shortly before midnight.  The bow echo produced a measured wind gust of 106 MPH in northern Warren County.  The high winds continued to push east along Interstate 80 for the next hour or so before it started to weaken.  The other major problem was with heavy rain.  The convection from the previous night set the stage by saturating soils.  The echos trained for several hours across central Iowa with very heavy rainfall.  Rainfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour were common under the heavier cells.  Several locations received 2 to 5 inch rainfalls in under  two hours, resulting in widespread flash flooding.  Reports of major highways being inundated by water were common.  By the end of the night, a swath of 4 to 9 inch rainfall was evident north of Interstate 80.  Longer term river flooding became a major problem by the morning of the 23rd.  There were two lightning related injuries.  Two people were injured when they were struck by lightning out of doors in Nevada.  The lightning struck close by as they were carrying groceries into their home.  The jolt caused them to fall, resulting in laceration to the head.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intermittent touchdown in fields west of Alleman.
The tornado touched down briefly over open rangeland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Once again it was a very active severe weather day over Iowa.  The frontal system that had moved through the state on the night of the 22nd was returning north as a warm front.  This time Iowa did not get completely into the warm sector.  The surface front was dragged north into Iowa by low pressure that moved out of Kansas northeast into central Iowa by the mid to late evening.  The airmass was pushed southeast out of the state by a cold front that passed through the state during the evening and early morning hours.  The airmass in the warm sector became very unstable.  Lifted indices were around -13 C with CAPE values greater than 5000 J/kg by the late afternoon.  The air advected north into Iowa during the day and into the evening.  Thunderstorms erupted in two places.  The first to affect the DSM CWA was the development of several elevated supercells over west central into southwest Iowa.  The storms continued to lift east and northeast across the area.  A few tornadoes touched down, however with the very elevated nature of the storms it was very difficult for the tornadoes to reach the ground.  By the late afternoon, a solid squall line developed along the cold front.  The line took on a Line Echo Wave Pattern by evening.  Several segments of the line bowed out, resulting in high winds.  At times the winds reached 80 MPH.  One of the thunderstorms produced high winds in the Early area of Sac County.  They overturned a semi-tractortrailer truck, causing $80,000 damage and causing minor injuries to the driver.  Tornadoes that formed along this line actually formed where the Rear Flank Downdraft cut through the line.  A clear meso was formed and the small tornadoes advanced around the meso and were in front of the thunderstorm line.  Touchdowns were all brief.  Hail was common with the stronger storm, with much of it in the one to one and three-quarter inch in diameter.  Given the antecedent soil conditions in Iowa, flash flooding became a major issue.  Numerous counties reported flash flooding as rainfall of one to 4 inches in spots resulted in flooded highways.  The thunderstorms formed into an MCC by the early evening hours.  As they moved out of the state, they delivered one more punch to the state.  High winds developed in the wake of the complex.  Several counties of north central, northeast, and central Iowa received high winds.  Damage occurred in several locations to both trees and out buildings.  Sustained winds across the area were in the 25 to 45 MPH range with some higher gusts.  Clarion reported a wind gust of 63 MPH for the highest wind gust reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down briefly in farm fields south of Earlham.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down briefly in a farm field along side of Interstate 35 at mile post 53.
This tornado tracked northeast across central portions of Jefferson Davis county and downed numerous trees along its path.

The tornado fist touched down near Georgetown in extreme western Floyd County. It moved east southeast nearly parallel to Indiana Highway 64. The tornado lifted near the Highway 64 interchange with Interstate 64, near Edwardsville. It reached its maximum intensity in the vicinity of Georgetown, where some F1 roof damage was noted. The tornado damaged approximately 25 homes in the Georgetown and Edwardsville areas, but most remained habitable. There was extensive damage to a few commercial buildings and businesses. There was extensive tree damage along Indiana Highway 64 between Georgetown and Edwardsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass was over Iowa and helped kick off the seasons first severe weather outbreak.  At the surface a warm frontal boundary extended nearly east to west across the state and provided the focus for thunderstorm development.  By the late afternoon, lifted indices were approaching -10 C. with CAPE values around 5000 J/kg over western Iowa.  Surface temperatures warmed into the upper 80s with dew points in the low to mid 70s.  A southwest surface wind of 15 to 25 kts pushed over the front.  Northeast of the frontal boundary winds were easterly around 10 to 15 kts.  Actually, the surface boundary was further enhanced by outflow from convective complexes during the day, further sharpening the contrast.  Thunderstorms continued to fire along and north of the boundary through the afternoon and into the evening.  This resulted in widespread flash flooding as very heavy rains fell on areas that had had significant rainfall the previous night.  There were reports in north central into northeast Iowa of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall in a little more than an hours time.  Major flooding took place in the Mason City area where evacuations were taking place.  The thunderstorms became most intense during the afternoon into the early evening.  There were several tornadoes across northeast into north central Iowa.  Most were relatively brief touchdowns and were in open areas.  Reports of multi-vortex tornadoes were received from Grundy County.  The days most significant tornado touched down in Pocahontas County east of Rolfe and tracked into Humboldt County through the Bradgate area.  The tornado damaged or destroyed over 75% of the town of Bradgate (pop 120).  Tornado damage in Bradgate was very extensive impacting most of the town.  Hardly a building was not impacted.   Outbuildings, light structures and garages were heavily damaged or destroyed.  Two homes were destroyed.  Several homes were damaged ranging from minor to extensive.  The Survey Team found that the majority of the damage was F1, with a few cases of F2 damage.  The F2 damage was to the snapping of very large trees just west of town and the structural damage to two buildings.  Nearly all of the 53 homes there reported damage with several totally destroyed.  Significant widespread property damage was reported in the tornadoes path.  There were several injuries in the town, the most significant being a broken leg.  A police officer was reportedly hit by debris from the tornado and suffered a broken leg.  According to law officials, the damage path of the tornado was 2 miles wide and about 8 miles long.  Storm chasers on the scene reported the tornado itself to be one half mile wide at one point.  Reports of hail were numerous through the afternoon and evening.  Most of the hail was in the three quarter inch to one inch diameter range.  There were a few reports of golf ball size hail from the stronger storms.  Winds were not a major problem with the activity.  There were spotty reports of winds to around 60 MPH, but most reports were in the 40 to 50 MPH range.  One of the stronger wind reports was a 64 MPH wind gust in Tripoli in Bremer County.  This gust was measured by a mesonet station there.  During the mid evening hours, thunderstorms rumbled across Grundy County.  Lightning struck the Sheriff's office there and destroyed a significant amount of office equipment.  Damage was reported around $100,000.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down in farm fields southwest of Dike.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado tracked southeast in open fields, just missing the town of Rolfe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms affected the northeast Permian Basin of west Texas during the late afternoon and evening of the 25th. These storms developed near a dryline/cold front triple point. A highly visible tornado was observed by many residents of Snyder in Scurry County. The parent thunderstorm produced large hail it tracked northeast over the city. A second supercell tracked east, then southeast across northern Mitchell County. This storm produced two tornadoes, baseball size hail, and damaging winds in the vicinity of Colorado City and Loraine.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was observed by several Snyder residents to the southwest of the city. The tornado remained over open country west of U.S. Highway 350 and resulted in no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of May 21st a severe thunderstorm produced 3/4 inch diameter hail in a swath from near Airway Heights to just south of the city of Spokane. In places this hail accumulated to a depth of over  4 inches. This storm also produced a short lived tornado near Fairchild Air Force Base. The tornado was confined to a relatively unpopulated area with minor damage to a barn and other outbuildings reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down in open fields.  Dust debris blown across highway 14 as it crossed.  The track was intermittent and the tornado was reported to be multiple vortex at times with two tornadoes on the ground at one point northeast of Grundy Center.
The tornado touched down briefly over an open field and was easily seen by trained spotters near Callaway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system in combination with the dryline resulted in several severe thunderstorms over much of the Big Country and western Concho Valley. Initially, the storms were supercells and produced a few tornadoes in Haskell County. The storms quickly transitioned into linear storms, some of which tracked over the same general areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter from a radio station reported a brief tornado just south of Haskell.
A Department of Public Safety trooper observed the tornado "touch down and then go right back up".

The tornado crossed from Stark County into Marshall County four tenths of a mile northwest of Camp Grove.  It initially blew down numerous trees and power lines until it reached the intersection of 1300N and 250E where it destroyed a shed and a pole barn which had farm equipment in it.  The farm equipment was damaged with damage estimated around $250,000.  It then continued moving northeast blowing a grain bin into a field, blew down more trees and power lines then crossed into Bureau County (WFO DVN county warning area) west of Whitefield.  No injuries were reported.

A tornado touched down 3 miles northwest of Victoria and traveled to the northeast.  As it reached the intersection of 2500N and 1700E, it destroyed one farm building and damaged two other farm buildings. It continued to move to the northeast lifting 4.5 miles north of Victoria.  Several trees and power lines were blown down as well.  No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept across west central Texas on the afternoon of the 27th. The worst damage was by far in Sweetwater, where golf ball size hail and winds of 80 mph left no home untouched on the south side of Sweetwater.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado, possibly a gustnado was observed at the Big Country Truck Stop just east of Merkel. Several eyewitness accounts report seeing the twister move across the far end of the parking lot and then move across Interstate 20. Other than power poles being snapped, no damage was noted.
This weak tornado briefly touched down 7 miles west northwest of Collins and damaged a mobile home, sheared many trees about 15 feet above the ground and downed several large trees.

This tornado moved out of Walthall county 1 mile southeast of Jayess and continued to track to the northeast before dissipating 6 miles east of Topeka. As the tornado moved northeast it snapped and uprooted dozens of trees.

A tornado was recorded on video by law enforcement as it crossed Highway 14 east of Revere.  The tornado downed trees on either side of the road.  The remainder of the tornado's path included open fields where little if any damage occurred.

The tornado traveled across mainly rural areas where little if any damage occurred. However, one farm 4 miles north of Sanborn sustained significant damage when the tornado struck a large shop made of clay blocks. The building was destroyed and many of the tools inside the building were damaged.  Debris from the building was scattered across nearby fields.  A metal corn crib was also damaged on the farm.
A small tornado hit the Raintree Plantation northwest of Hillsboro. Three homes suffered minor roof damage, a boat dock was damaged, and trees and power lines were down.

The tornado first touched down IN an open area east of Smithfield in southwest Henry County. It then moved east and crossed highway 55 north of Eminence. The tornado reached its maximum intensity as it moved between U.S. 421 and the Eminence-Point Pleasant Road. The tornado finally crossed Sweeney Lane and weakened or lifted. South of the tornado path, straight line winds caused some structural damage along with widespread tree damage. Twenty-five homes were destroyed in the storm, and 326 others received some degree of damage.

The tornado first touched down just east of Masterson Station Park on the subdivision road of Buck Lane. It continued east through the subdivision, causing F2 damage. The tornado then crossed an open field and creek, entering another subdivision. It appeared that the tornado reached its maximum F3 intensity in this section of the path. The tornado was on the ground intermittently as it moved to the east northeast. It struck a single house on State Road 1978, doing F2 damage. It crossed Georgetown Road and struck another subdivision near Citation Boulevard, doing F1 to F2 damage. It continued for a short distance into a field, and then lifted. There was straight line wind damage to the south of the tornado path, and additional straight line wind damage to the east after the tornado lifted. The tornado damaged 15 homes to some degree, and at least 50 home received moderate to severe damage. The hardest hit area was the Masterson Station subdivision.
Klondike Park officials reported a brief tornado that downed some trees in the park.
A small tornado downed some trees and caused roof damage to some outbuildings near the small community of Detters. The tornado formed near Highway T and tracked southeast along Fiddle Creek Road.
A tornado touched down briefly in open country.
A tornado touched down briefly in open country.

This time Iowa did not get completely into the warm sector. Hail was common with the stronger storm, with much of it in the one to one and three-quarter inch in diameter.  Given the antecedent soil conditions in Iowa, flash flooding became a major issue.  Numerous counties reported flash flooding as rainfall of one to 4 inches in spots resulted in flooded highways.  The thunderstorms formed into an MCC by the early evening hours. Several counties of north central, northeast, and central Iowa received high winds.  Damage occurred in several locations to both trees and out buildings.  Sustained winds across the area were in the 25 to 45 MPH range with some higher gusts.  Clarion reported a wind gust of 63 MPH for the highest wind gust reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado touchdown in open fields south of Mt Ayr.
Tornado mainly moved over open country shredding trees.  However, one roof was completely destroyed.
Considerable tree damage along the path.  Several trees were completely uprooted.
The tornado hit a machine shop and caused considerable damage.
This brief tornado was observed by storm chasers damaging some trees before dissipating.
A very brief, narrow tornado was seen by storm chasers in open country. No damage was reported.
This brief tornado, which was observed by a media helicopter, caused damage to the roof of the Alfalfa Fire Department and a nearby barn on Highway 58.
A media helicopter observed this brief tornado which heavily damaged a mobile home east of Eakly on Highway 152.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado associated with a low-topped supercell touched down a quarter of a mile south of the Boone/Hendricks county line in Hendricks county. The tornado continued northeast through Jamestown and into Boone county causing significant damage to a dozen homes. 2 homes had their roofs blown completely off and tossed several hundred feet into a corn field. There were 8 minor injuries including one man whose semi was blown over along Interstate 74. Estimated wind speeds were around 110 mph or on the high end of an F1 rating.

A weak tornado was spawned in western Polk County about 5 miles west of Rocky. The tornado briefly touched down before dissipating. Mostly tree damage was noted, with small trees and large tree limbs downed.

A weak tornado was spawned in southeast Polk County about 8 miles southeast of Big Fork. The tornado pushed over a few trees and downed large tree limbs before moving into southwest Montgomery County.

A weak tornado moved from southeast Polk County into southwest Montgomery County. The tornado affected areas 13 to 14 miles southwest of Black Springs, and caused mostly tree damage. The tornado was on the ground for almost 2 miles before dissipating.

A weak tornado was spawned in northeast Pike County about 5 miles south-southeast of Glenwood. The tornado initially was very weak, with tree limbs downed and tree tops removed. The tornado strengthened as it headed into western Clark County.
The tornado destroyed a barn.
A tornado briefly touched down in rural country and then completely lifted.
This tornado remained in rural country. It was produced by the same thunderstorm that produced the  tornado minutes earlier in the same county (McIntosh).
Brief tornado touchdown caught on video near exit 116 on I-29.

A tornado briefly touched down in the extreme eastern part of Shelby county. One house had some shingle damage and second home had a window blown out. A horse trailer was blown about 40 feet and a pickup truck was pushed about 25 feet. Several trees were knocked down.
A storm chaser shot video of  two brief F0 tornadoes southwest of Haskell.  Damage was limited to blown down tree limbs and uprooted trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The second in a series of tornadoes associated with an isolated low-topped supercell touched down in rural Howard county 8 miles southwest of Kokomo. The tornado was rated an F0 and destroyed a barn and overturned a grain bin in its brief lifetime.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A third in a string of tornadoes associated with an isolated low-topped supercell touched down in Kokomo. The tornado was rated an F1 and severely damaged a skating rink and trucking company. There was also damage to 3 other homes and 1 minor injury reported.

As the tornado crossed from Douglas County into Champaign County, 3 miles southwest of Pesotum, it destroyed a barn as well as several trees and power lines. The tornado lifted and dissipated 2 miles south southwest of Pesotum.  No injuries were reported.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field.  No damage or injuries were reported.

A narrow tornado was reported by law enforcement and caught on video by a storm chaser north of Hadar. The tornado damaged several buildings in the area including a garage, a house and a few small farm outbuildings.  The tornado also downed power lines near Hadar knocking out the power to part of town. The tornado was visible from the northern sections of Norfolk before lifting.
This F0 tornado is the second brief tornado video taped by a storm chaser.
A F0 tornado briefly touched down in a neighborhood in the northeast part of the city of Broken Arrow.  Damage was mainly limited to trees.
The storm which produced the tornado in the northeast part of Broken Arrow produced this F0 tornado which traveled through rural areas of Wagoner county blowing down trees and damaging outbuildings.
A F1 tornado briefly touched down just northeast of Strickler.  Damage was confined to broken tree limbs and blown down trees.

A tornado touched down 6.5 miles east of Wyoming (Stark County).  As it traveled east, it blew out 5 windows on a house and damaged the roof of a barn. Also, numerous trees were either uprooted or snapped off. The tornado then crossed from Stark County into Marshall County 7.3 miles east northeast of Wyoming.  No injuries were reported.

A weak tornado was spawned in northern Pike County about 2 miles northwest of the Lodi community. The tornado snapped some trees and blew a few trees down. The tornado was on the ground about 2.5 miles before dissipating just northeast of Lodi.

A tornado touched down at the intersection of 1300N and 750E in northwestern Douglas County.  In this location it damaged the front porch of a home, destroyed the garage, damaged a couple of sheds and blew down several large trees.  When the garage collapsed it damaged a 1975 Corvette, as well as another car and two antique tractors.  The tornado then traveled to the north northeast damaging an abandoned home, before crossing from Douglas County into Champaign County, 5.7 miles north northwest of Tuscola.  No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system in combination with the dryline resulted in several severe thunderstorms over much of the Big Country and western Concho Valley. Initially, the storms were supercells and produced a few tornadoes in Haskell County. The storms quickly transitioned into linear storms, some of which tracked over the same general areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser reported another tornado with the same mesocyclone from the first tornadoes. He also noted that there was another meso forming just to the east of their location on highway 380.
This weak tornado briefly touched down and twisted a few limbs on a few trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic situation was very similar to what it was the previous day.  A complex weather situation was in place due to the convection from the previous night.  An outflow boundary extended east to west across northern Missouri.  The synoptic frontal boundary extended from central Nebraska across northern Iowa.  The air was clear over Iowa during the day, allowing for temperatures to recover.  Dew point values also recovered quite rapidly with readings in the upper 60s to low 70s by the late afternoon hours.  Lifted indices dropped into the -5 to -10 C. range by evening with CAPE values approaching 5000 J/kg.  By the evening hours, the frontal boundary and outflow boundary had converged and were located along Interstate 80.  Explosive thunderstorm development took place during the very late afternoon and evening hours in spite of the weak shear profile.  Discrete supercells formed in a narrow line along Interstate 80 from near Des Moines on west.  The storms became tornadic quickly.  To add insult to injury, a strong thunderstorm complex formed over Nebraska and moved east along the line of convection over Iowa.  As the event took shape, all modes of severe weather occurred.  The storms developed so rapidly that there was little more than a half hour from the first hail and wind report to the first tornado touchdown.  Hail and high wind reports were too numerous to mention individually here.  Numerous reports of golf ball size hail were received.  Boone and Story Counties reported some of the largest hail with the event as baseball size hail pelted the are.  There was one report of very large hail northwest of Slater in Story County.  Hail five and one half inches in diameter punched 8 holes through a steel roof.  There was severe house siding and roof damage in the area.  There were numerous tornadoes, especially in the central Iowa Iowa.  At one point there were several supercells around the metropolitan Des Moines area.  Two of the stronger tornadoes touched down west and south of Des Moines.  Fortunately, most of the tornado tracks were over open areas and resulted in little damage.  High winds became a problem, especially after sunset, as the complex from Nebraska moved in.  The system became more of a derecho during the late night hours.  Eighty plus MPH winds pelted southwest Iowa and downed barns and several buildings in Adams and Cass Counties.  A beta bow element formed in central Iowa shortly before midnight.  The bow echo produced a measured wind gust of 106 MPH in northern Warren County.  The high winds continued to push east along Interstate 80 for the next hour or so before it started to weaken.  The other major problem was with heavy rain.  The convection from the previous night set the stage by saturating soils.  The echos trained for several hours across central Iowa with very heavy rainfall.  Rainfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour were common under the heavier cells.  Several locations received 2 to 5 inch rainfalls in under  two hours, resulting in widespread flash flooding.  Reports of major highways being inundated by water were common.  By the end of the night, a swath of 4 to 9 inch rainfall was evident north of Interstate 80.  Longer term river flooding became a major problem by the morning of the 23rd.  There were two lightning related injuries.  Two people were injured when they were struck by lightning out of doors in Nevada.  The lightning struck close by as they were carrying groceries into their home.  The jolt caused them to fall, resulting in laceration to the head.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bief tornado touchdown in fields northeast of Newton.

A small tornado touched down briefly in the southeast part of the town of Scipio in southern Cayuga County near Mathers Road.  The tornado tracked east southeast before lifting before it hit the southern end of Owasco Lake.  The tornado's path length was about one half mile long with a width of about 75 yards.   Maximum winds with this tornado were estimated to be 70 mph.  The tornado knocked down or uprooted many trees along its path.  There was also minor damage to about 10 structures.  Most of the structural damage was to shingles and siding.  There was 1 home that had part of its roof blown off.  A small boat was overturned and a row boat was blown up into a tree by the tornado.  Other areas of southern Cayuga County had damage from straight line thunderstorm winds.

A weak tornado moved from Yell County into southern Pope County. The tornado tracked through the Holla Bend National Wildlife Refuge, and pushed over several trees. The tornado dissipated a little over 8 miles south of Pottsville.

A weak tornado was spawned in western Johnson County about 3 miles north-northeast of Hunt. The tornado caused mostly tree damage, with some trees blown over. The tornado dissipated a couple of miles northeast of Ludwig.

A weak tornado was spawned in northern Van Buren County roughly 1 to 2 miles southeast of Crabtree. The tornado did little more than skirt some tree tops before dissipating about a mile northwest of Clinton.
A weak tornado was spawned in southern Lonoke County roughly 3 miles northeast of Pettus. The tornado was only on the ground for a few minutes, and caused minor tree damage.

A weak tornado touched down in Calhoun County, about 13 miles south-southeast of Hampton.  The tornado tracked to the east and eventually lifted 6 miles south-southeast of Harrell.  The only damage noted along the path of the tornado were some large limbs blown down and a few small trees knocked down.

A weak tornado briefly touched down in western Bradley County, just to the northwest of Jersey.  A tree was blown down onto a house causing only minor roof damage.  The only other damage noted along the tornado path were a number of downed tree limbs and some small trees blown down.

An F1 tornado tracked across the northern portion of Bradley County, to the southwest of Warren.  The only damage noted along the path of the tornado were a number of large trees that were blown down, with several of them falling in county roads.

A F1 tornado touched down just northeast of Mazie and lasted until it lifted just east of Murphy.  Much of the path contained of F0 damage consisting of roof damage to a home, a broken window in a home and damage to outbuildings.  F1 damage occurred near the Neosho River where a mobile home was overturned and several large trees were snapped off.
A F0 tornado briefly touched down east of Coweta.  No damage was found on the storm survey.  The occurrence was documented by witnesses.
Sighted between El Campo and Danevang.
Tornado moved northeast across an open field before taking direct aim on Chaparral High School.  The tornado ripped off the pressbox of the football stadium and peeled back part of the roof.

The lightning struck close by as they were carrying groceries into their home.  The jolt caused them to fall, resulting in laceration to the head.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief touchdown in open fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This severe weather episode was similar to the one the week before, where there was a strong upper level system in combination with a southward moving canadian cold front and eastward moving dryline. The combination of these features resulted in severe thunderstorms over portions of the Big Country and Heartland. The hardest hit area was Albany where very large hail fell for several minutes resulting in damage to property.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Texas state trooper reported a tornado near Glen Cove.  The tornado was over open country and produced no visible damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second tornado, associated with a low-topped supercell that damaged homes in the Jamestown area, touched down in rural Boone county. Eyewitnesses reported funnel clouds and scattered damage along the path.
Caused minimal damage to roof of a home.
A brief F0 tornado occurred just west northwest of Sapulpa. No damage was reported.

A mini-supercell embedded in a squall line produced an F0 tornado from 1 miles northwest to 2 miles north of Muldrow. A carport and barn were destroyed and shingles were torn from the roof of a home.  Several trees were also blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey team found F0 damage to trees and power lines with a few power poles snapped off from east of Fairmount to near Upland. The tornado was skipping along the 4 mile path length and was around 100 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey team found a brief touchdown in a field near Point Isabel with no discernible damage.
A brief tornado caused no reported damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Once again it was a very active severe weather day over Iowa.  The frontal system that had moved through the state on the night of the 22nd was returning north as a warm front.  This time Iowa did not get completely into the warm sector.  The surface front was dragged north into Iowa by low pressure that moved out of Kansas northeast into central Iowa by the mid to late evening.  The airmass was pushed southeast out of the state by a cold front that passed through the state during the evening and early morning hours.  The airmass in the warm sector became very unstable.  Lifted indices were around -13 C with CAPE values greater than 5000 J/kg by the late afternoon.  The air advected north into Iowa during the day and into the evening.  Thunderstorms erupted in two places.  The first to affect the DSM CWA was the development of several elevated supercells over west central into southwest Iowa.  The storms continued to lift east and northeast across the area.  A few tornadoes touched down, however with the very elevated nature of the storms it was very difficult for the tornadoes to reach the ground.  By the late afternoon, a solid squall line developed along the cold front.  The line took on a Line Echo Wave Pattern by evening.  Several segments of the line bowed out, resulting in high winds.  At times the winds reached 80 MPH.  One of the thunderstorms produced high winds in the Early area of Sac County.  They overturned a semi-tractortrailer truck, causing $80,000 damage and causing minor injuries to the driver.  Tornadoes that formed along this line actually formed where the Rear Flank Downdraft cut through the line.  A clear meso was formed and the small tornadoes advanced around the meso and were in front of the thunderstorm line.  Touchdowns were all brief.  Hail was common with the stronger storm, with much of it in the one to one and three-quarter inch in diameter.  Given the antecedent soil conditions in Iowa, flash flooding became a major issue.  Numerous counties reported flash flooding as rainfall of one to 4 inches in spots resulted in flooded highways.  The thunderstorms formed into an MCC by the early evening hours.  As they moved out of the state, they delivered one more punch to the state.  High winds developed in the wake of the complex.  Several counties of north central, northeast, and central Iowa received high winds.  Damage occurred in several locations to both trees and out buildings.  Sustained winds across the area were in the 25 to 45 MPH range with some higher gusts.  Clarion reported a wind gust of 63 MPH for the highest wind gust reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was a brief touchdown in open areas.  The tornado itself was actually embedded within a large area of straight line winds.

The following were damaged or destroyed: 15 farm dwellings and service buildings, and 30 pieces of farm machinery and equipment. (This portion of narrative courtesy of USDA Flash Flood Situation report.) One home unroofed resulting in damage to most of property inside. Widespread damage to wheat fields that had been ready for harvest.
The following were damaged: the roof of one home, several outbuildings, and the adjacent wheat fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system in combination with the dryline resulted in several severe thunderstorms over much of the Big Country and western Concho Valley. Initially, the storms were supercells and produced a few tornadoes in Haskell County. The storms quickly transitioned into linear storms, some of which tracked over the same general areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser saw a multiple vortex tornado lasting several minutes move just south of highway 380.
This brief tornado touched down in an open field and caused no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low-topped supercell produced an F1 tornado near Frankfort. The tornado destroyed 2 garages and a high school scoreboard and also damaged a barn.
Brief touchdown in open country.
Tornado mainly moved through a wheat field, however, it did produce considerable tree damage and minor damage to one roof.
Reported by a spotter for a television station.
Brief landspout tornado. Tore off part of a metal roof from a local business.
The tornado mainly moved over open country damaging wheat fields that were ready to be harvested, however, one home completely lost it's roof and most of the belongings inside.
Brief touchdown in open country.

An F1 tornado touched down 2 miles west-southwest of Fordyce and was on the ground for about 2 miles before lifting 1.5 miles northwest of Fordyce.  The path of this tornado was almost entirely within the city limits of Fordyce, on the west side of town.  At a discount store, patio furniture and swing sets were destroyed and a garden center was damaged.  A church steeple was blown off and some wood fences were knocked down.  Several large trees were uprooted, with one tree landing on a house.  Dozens of moderate to large size tree limbs were also knocked down.

A weak tornado touched down about 4.1 miles southwest of the town of Ivan on Dallas County.  The tornado was on the ground for approximately 4.2 miles before lifting 3 miles northwest of Ivan.  A pole barn was destroyed, a trampoline and swing set at a residence were also blown around.  A number of large tree limbs were also knocked down.
Storm chasers reported a brief tornado over open country.  No damage resulted from the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey team found F0 damage to trees from east of Huntington to southeast of Roanoke. The tornado was skipping along a 6 mile wide path and was 50 yards wide.

The emergency manager of Pierce county followed this tornado for nearly 6 miles.  The tornado touched down from a different storm that produced the tornado a few minutes earlier to the west of Pierce.  This tornado also remained in open fields and caused no apparent damage.
A storm spotter reported a small tornado that lasted about one minute.
A weak tornado was reported southwest of Seminole.
A tornado was observed by a Texas Department of Public Safety trooper moving east at ten mph.  The tornado moved over rural areas with no damage noted.
Sighted near the intersection of FM 418 and Hwy 71.

A weak tornado was spawned in eastern Logan County a little more than a mile west of New Blaine. As the tornado touched down, it tore the roof off of a porch and threw it into a creek 75 yards away. About 4 miles southeast of New Blaine, an uprooted tree raised up the end of a house trailer. Another tree fell on two pickup trucks, with a shed destroyed. The tornado eventually tracked into northern Yell County.

A weak tornado tracked from eastern Logan County into northern Yell County. As it entered Yell County, the tornado gradually weakened, with some trees knocked down. The tornado dissipated 4 to 5 miles west of Dardanelle.

As one weak tornado dissipated in northern Yell County, another one formed 4 to 5 miles southwest of Dardanelle. The new tornado caused mostly tree damage, with trees downed or snapped. The tornado eventually tracked into southern Pope County.
A weak tornado was spawned in northern Conway County roughly 4 to 5 miles east-northeast of Cleveland. The tornado briefly touched down and caused some minor tree damage before dissipating.
The tornado touched down briefly over open rangeland.
The tornado touched down briefly over an open field near the O'Neill Country Club.  Large tree limbs were broken off at the Country Club.
The tornado touched down briefly over open rangeland.
While the tornado made a brief touchdown, it destroyed a weak barn.

The storm that produced a weak tornado in northern Conway County spawned yet another weak tornado in southern Van Buren County almost 2 miles east of Scotland. This latest tornado caused minor tree damage before dissipating.
This weak tornado briefly touched down southwest of Reganton and downed and snapped a number of trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very cold air aloft moved in over Iowa under a closed low pressure system aloft.  With strong heating and steep lapse rates, the atmosphere became very unstable.  A strong dust devil formed in Des Moines at a softball field and injured 5 small girls there.  One of the girls, each 5 to 6 years old, was actually picked p off the ground.  She was treated for a fractured ankle.  Later in the afternoon, convection became stronger.  Small showers developed and there reports of cold air funnels.  A landspout touched down in Hancock County north of Hayfield.  The landspout tracked southeast for about 3 miles before dissipating.  It tracked through open fields and did not cause any damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tracked across open fields for about 3 miles.
Brief touchdown in open country.

Large dusty tornado moved north just on the outskirts of the city.  The tornado had a direct hit on an ECO block home.  The home lost it's roof, but all exterior walls remained in tact.  Two metal barns were also lost in the tornado.
Tornado moved through open country only causing damage to trees.
Large tornado moved over open country before hitting a farmstead and shearing off the roof of a veterinarians clinic and the top floor of a two story home.
A F1 tornado occurred from just southwest of Mannford to just south of Mannford.  The tornado damaged a few homes and several outbuildings and barns.  It also uprooted some trees.
A tornado was reported near the town of Pecos.
Tornado sighted by trained spotter.
The tornado made a brief touchdown over open rangeland.

The tornado entered LaSalle County from Putnam County, approximately 3 miles northeast of the town of Standard, producing F0 intensity damage in a wooded area southwest of Peru.  As the tornado continued northeast, F2 intensity damage was done to several homes in a subdivision near the intersection of East 250th and 2569th Roads.  Several roofs were blown off homes along with damage to external walls.  Significant tree damage was done as well.  Path width was estimated at 50 yards at this location.  The tornado then continued northeast, crossing the Illinois River twice as it moved toward the town of Utica, downing a steel high tension tower on the north bank of the river, immediately west of Illinois 251.  The tornado moved into the southwest side of Utica where it was F0 intensity. Homes along Washington Street only had tree and minor roof damage. A church steeple was damaged on Division between Johnson and Washington. Roofs and trees were more severely damaged on the south side of Johnson Street. The tornado rapidly increased to F3 intensity on the north side of Johnson Street where one home had its roof taken off and north walls blown out. A machinery building was completely destroyed on the south side of the canal and a semi-tractor trailer was blown into the canal. A large grain bin was blown across the canal and flattened. The tornado then moved north of the canal into the heart of town where several homes were severely damaged, garages were destroyed and brick buildings collapsed. Eight people died and seven were rescued from the basement of a turn of the century sandstone building at Clark and Church Streets. The tornado was approximately 250 yards wide at this point. On the east edge of the vortex along Mill Street, in downtown, buildings suffered damage to facades, roofs and windows. East of Mill Street there was damage to trees and minor roof damage. In the northeast section of town a mobile home was overturned on Grove, just east of Mill Street. The vortex crossed the railroad tracks and apparently dissipated on a steep bluff on the northeast side of town. At the top of the hill there were some trees and limbs down and some debris deposited.  See Storm Data for Northwest and Central Illinois for results of Tornado Damage Survey for Putnam and Bureau Counties, IL
A tornado touched down briefly in rural areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system in combination with the dryline resulted in several severe thunderstorms over much of the Big Country and western Concho Valley. Initially, the storms were supercells and produced a few tornadoes in Haskell County. The storms quickly transitioned into linear storms, some of which tracked over the same general areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser saw another tornado moving from north to the south across highway 380 just to the east of Irby. The storm became outflow dominate. There were several reports of gustnadoes after this tornado. However, this is the last report of an actual tornado.

Along the path of the tornado, 6 homes received minor to moderate damage from falling trees and roof damage. A roof was also peeled off a church. Numerous trees were snapped off and blown down as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather event affected Texas and Oklahoma on the 3rd and 4th of March. Elevated severe thunderstorms first erupted across West Texas and far southeast New Mexico late in the evening on the 3rd. The activity increased in intensity and coverage through the night over the Permian Basin and Trans Pecos regions of Texas as a warm front moved north to the Interstate 20 corridor. Widely scattered supercell storms moved along the boundary over the southeast Permian Basin during the very early morning hours.  The convection then evolved into a broken squall line as it began to quickly spread east.  Several bookend vortices, line echo wave patterns, and bow segments were observed in the Doppler radar imagery across the eastern Permian Basin. A total of four weak tornadoes were confirmed to be associated with these signatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A delayed report from a local farmer indicated that a tornado tracked across his property in southeastern Glasscock County. A shed was destroyed and the rafters of a large barn were broken by the tornadic winds. In addition, four utility poles were snapped. The farmer described a well-defined and narrow path through shredded mesquite trees in his pasture.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey team found F1 damage near Lincolnville with two homes heavily damaged and a barn destroyed. The tornado was skipping as it moved along a 2 mile path length and was around 150 yards wide at the widest point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey team found F0 damage to five homes and in trees southwest of Huntington. The tornado was skipping along a three and one half mile path and was around 50 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On April 20th, 2004 a warm front located across central Indiana in the afternoon began to move north in the evening as a strong southerly flow rode over the front, creating an favorable environment for rapid thunderstorm development. Favorable wind shear existed along the boundary with east to southeast surface winds north of the boundary and south to southwest surface winds just south of the boundary, leading to the rapid evolution of the storms into rotating supercells. One of these supercells was responsible for tornadoes in Miami, Wabash, and Huntington counties, with other storms producing two tornadoes in Grant county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported a brief tornado touchdown near Amboy. NWS survey found swirling in field. Tornado was skipping as it moved east northeast. Path length was about one mile near Amboy with with no discernable damage and rated F0.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system in combination with the dryline resulted in several severe thunderstorms over much of the Big Country and western Concho Valley. Initially, the storms were supercells and produced a few tornadoes in Haskell County. The storms quickly transitioned into linear storms, some of which tracked over the same general areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser saw another tornado as a brief dust whirl underneath the cloud circulation. The tornado lasted less than one minute.
A tornado destroyed a shed, damaged a car, tore the back off a garage, and moved a house slightly from its foundation.
A tornado touched down briefly but did no damage.
A brief tornado caused no reported damage.
A tornado caused tree damage, including several trees blown down. The tornado also blew down power lines, causing local power outages.
A tornado destroyed a barn and blew the walls of a garage off its foundation. The garage was attached to a house which received no apparent damage.
A brief, pencil-like tornado was observed in open country. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: 3 low-topped supercell thunderstorms dropped down at least 1 tornado a piece and a total of 6 tornadoes across Central Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening of April 20. All of the tornadoes were F0 or F1 in rating. The worst damage occurred in Kokomo as 3 homes were damaged and a skating rink and trucking company had significant damage totaling around 3 million dollars. There were also 1 minor injury. The town of Jamestown along the Hendricks/Boone county border also was hit hard with significant damage to a dozen homes totaling 1.65 million dollars.  There were also 8 minor injuries, 1 as a result of his semi being overturned along Interstate 74.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado associated with a low-topped supercell touched down a quarter of a mile south of the Boone/Hendricks county line in Hendricks county. The tornado continued northeast through Jamestown and into Boone county causing significant damage to a dozen homes. 2 homes had their roofs blown completely off and tossed several hundred feet into a corn field. There were 8 minor injuries including one man whose semi was blown over along Interstate 74. Estimated wind speeds were around 110 mph or on the high end of an F1 rating.
A brief tornado caused no reported damage.
A brief tornado touchdown was reported near Boyd.  One barn was destroyed and another was damaged.Some 2 by 4's were impaled in a fence.
Trees, powerlines, and barns were blown down.  A mobile home was damaged and a carport was destroyed.

The following were destroyed: 15 farm dwellings and service buildings, 25 pieces of farm machinery and equipment, many miles of transmission line, with most of wheat a total loss. (This portion of narrative courtesy of USDA Flash Situation Report.) In addition, major damage to several homes along highway 49.  One modular was completely removed from over a viewout basement.  A teenage boy sought refuge under the staircase in the basement only to watch a car thrown overhead. He escaped unharmed. However, one woman wasn't so fortunate; the resident of a mobile home that was completely destroyed. The only recognizable parts were the steel girders that ran along the base of the home. She had sought refuge in the bathroom and was holding on to the commode. She was thrown several feet from the homestead and received several injuries. Fortunately, none were serious.

Considerable damage to two homesteads; the first being a sturdy brick home. All exterior walls ripped from the home, only leaving only the interior. Home owner ran down the stairs as the tornado hit and avoided injury.  Further southeast, a modular home was completely removed from above a viewout basement. It was here that an amazing survival occurred. The homeowner sought refuge in a safe room in the basement and was unharmed, despite the fact a propane tank landed in the basement and began to leak. Breathing became difficult as fumes permeated the saferoom. At the same time, the saferoom began to flood, however the rising water levels dissipated the fumes. In addition, a semi-truck was thrown approximately 100 feet.
Tornado did considerable damage to a couple of roofs and almost wiped out a mobile home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic situation was very similar to what it was the previous day.  A complex weather situation was in place due to the convection from the previous night.  An outflow boundary extended east to west across northern Missouri.  The synoptic frontal boundary extended from central Nebraska across northern Iowa.  The air was clear over Iowa during the day, allowing for temperatures to recover.  Dew point values also recovered quite rapidly with readings in the upper 60s to low 70s by the late afternoon hours.  Lifted indices dropped into the -5 to -10 C. range by evening with CAPE values approaching 5000 J/kg.  By the evening hours, the frontal boundary and outflow boundary had converged and were located along Interstate 80.  Explosive thunderstorm development took place during the very late afternoon and evening hours in spite of the weak shear profile.  Discrete supercells formed in a narrow line along Interstate 80 from near Des Moines on west.  The storms became tornadic quickly.  To add insult to injury, a strong thunderstorm complex formed over Nebraska and moved east along the line of convection over Iowa.  As the event took shape, all modes of severe weather occurred.  The storms developed so rapidly that there was little more than a half hour from the first hail and wind report to the first tornado touchdown.  Hail and high wind reports were too numerous to mention individually here.  Numerous reports of golf ball size hail were received.  Boone and Story Counties reported some of the largest hail with the event as baseball size hail pelted the are.  There was one report of very large hail northwest of Slater in Story County.  Hail five and one half inches in diameter punched 8 holes through a steel roof.  There was severe house siding and roof damage in the area.  There were numerous tornadoes, especially in the central Iowa Iowa.  At one point there were several supercells around the metropolitan Des Moines area.  Two of the stronger tornadoes touched down west and south of Des Moines.  Fortunately, most of the tornado tracks were over open areas and resulted in little damage.  High winds became a problem, especially after sunset, as the complex from Nebraska moved in.  The system became more of a derecho during the late night hours.  Eighty plus MPH winds pelted southwest Iowa and downed barns and several buildings in Adams and Cass Counties.  A beta bow element formed in central Iowa shortly before midnight.  The bow echo produced a measured wind gust of 106 MPH in northern Warren County.  The high winds continued to push east along Interstate 80 for the next hour or so before it started to weaken.  The other major problem was with heavy rain.  The convection from the previous night set the stage by saturating soils.  The echos trained for several hours across central Iowa with very heavy rainfall.  Rainfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour were common under the heavier cells.  Several locations received 2 to 5 inch rainfalls in under  two hours, resulting in widespread flash flooding.  Reports of major highways being inundated by water were common.  By the end of the night, a swath of 4 to 9 inch rainfall was evident north of Interstate 80.  Longer term river flooding became a major problem by the morning of the 23rd.  There were two lightning related injuries.  Two people were injured when they were struck by lightning out of doors in Nevada.  The lightning struck close by as they were carrying groceries into their home.  The jolt caused them to fall, resulting in laceration to the head.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down southwest of the town of Stuart and tracked northeast through mostly open countryside.  The tornado did lift occasionally.

Several mobile homes were blown over in Lively Oaks, the upper section of a communications tower was blown over, and numerous trees and barns were destroyed south of Graham.   The tornado track continued east northeast into Jack County before dissipating near Bryson.
The tornado entered Jack County from Young County approximately 3 miles southwest of Bryson then moved east northeast to about .5 miles south of Bryson before dissipating.
Brief tornado touchdown reported.
Brief tornado touchdown reported, with trees and power lines blown down.

The tornado touched down on the east side of Lavon Lake then moved northeast and dissipated approximately 2 miles north northwest of Copeville.  Damage occurred to mobile homes, houses, trees, and utility poles. 8 homes were left uninhabitable and 16 sustained heavy damage.  Two people were injured when the mobile home they were in was moved 150 feet.
Morehead City Police reported a sign blown down and minor damage to a house from a brief tornado touchdown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance combined with a strong surface low pressure system moving across West Central Texas produced a significant squall line that moved through the entire San Angelo county warning area. This squall line was accompanied by 60 to 80 MPH winds which produced widespread damage, especially across the Big Country. Embedded within the squall line, were several Supercell thunderstorms which produced nine tornadoes within the San Angelo county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous manufactured homes were damaged or destroyed by the tornado along Lake Stamford.
This was a brief "rope" reaching the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather event affected Texas and Oklahoma on the 3rd and 4th of March. Elevated severe thunderstorms first erupted across West Texas and far southeast New Mexico late in the evening on the 3rd. The activity increased in intensity and coverage through the night over the Permian Basin and Trans Pecos regions of Texas as a warm front moved north to the Interstate 20 corridor. Widely scattered supercell storms moved along the boundary over the southeast Permian Basin during the very early morning hours.  The convection then evolved into a broken squall line as it began to quickly spread east.  Several bookend vortices, line echo wave patterns, and bow segments were observed in the Doppler radar imagery across the eastern Permian Basin. A total of four weak tornadoes were confirmed to be associated with these signatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado struck the city of Loraine resulting in one injury and damage to several light-weight structures and vehicles.  Damage surveyed by a National Weather Service meteorologist began on the south side of the city near Looby Street. From there the tornado traveled northeast producing a one mile long damage path that cut across the southeast corner of the city to near Interstate 20. Along the path, a roof was partially removed from one home and several vehicles and trailers were damaged or destroyed. About $100,000 worth of musical equipment was destroyed when a cargo trailer was rolled by the tornado. The tornado began to dissipate as it crossed Interstate 20 on the east side of the city. Before doing so, it blew two semi-trucks off of the highway, injuring one driver. Several eye witnesses described seeing the tornado's condensation funnel and debris whirling beneath it.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather event affected Texas and Oklahoma on the 3rd and 4th of March. Elevated severe thunderstorms first erupted across West Texas and far southeast New Mexico late in the evening on the 3rd. The activity increased in intensity and coverage through the night over the Permian Basin and Trans Pecos regions of Texas as a warm front moved north to the Interstate 20 corridor. Widely scattered supercell storms moved along the boundary over the southeast Permian Basin during the very early morning hours.  The convection then evolved into a broken squall line as it began to quickly spread east.  Several bookend vortices, line echo wave patterns, and bow segments were observed in the Doppler radar imagery across the eastern Permian Basin. A total of four weak tornadoes were confirmed to be associated with these signatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado severely damaged two trailer homes and a few recreational vehicles in the Lake Champion vicinity along Highway 208 south of Colorado City. The roof was partially removed from one trailer house, and another was rolled onto its top. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance combined with a strong surface low pressure system moving across West Central Texas produced a significant squall line that moved through the entire San Angelo county warning area. This squall line was accompanied by 60 to 80 MPH winds which produced widespread damage, especially across the Big Country. Embedded within the squall line, were several Supercell thunderstorms which produced nine tornadoes within the San Angelo county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This is the same tornado that started near Potosi and moved into Callahan County. This tornado was also observed from the Abilene air traffic control tower.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front extending across southeast Missouri was the focus for tornadic thunderstorms. The storms developed during the warmth of the afternoon and produced a few tornadoes, isolated dime size hail, and several reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down about one mile south of the intersection of U.S. Highway 60 and County Highway 233 in eastern Carter County. The tornado tracked north-northeast, passing only about a mile west of the town of Ellsinore. The tornado damage path ended on County Road 365 less than one half mile before reaching the Wayne County line. Peak winds in the tornado were estimated at 150 MPH.  Most of the injured were in a mobile home on the north side of U.S. Highway 60. Their mobile home was picked up and thrown into some trees. One person was critically injured. The critically injured person was paralyzed when her back and neck was broken, and she was airlifted to a St. Louis area hospital. Another person received a broken arm, and most of the remaining injuries were scrapes and cuts. The tornado destroyed a total of three mobile homes, a storage facility, and numerous sheds. Two homes and one business were severely damaged. Numerous vehicles were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front extending across southeast Missouri was the focus for tornadic thunderstorms. The storms developed during the warmth of the afternoon and produced a few tornadoes, isolated dime size hail, and several reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were blown down. Two businesses and about six homes were severely damaged when most of their roofing was blown off. The businesses were a beauty shop and a post office. A dozen barns and sheds were destroyed. Several vehicles and some farm machinery was damaged. Peak winds were estimated near 100 MPH. Power outages affected about 100 people. Some county roads and secondary highways were blocked. The damage path began on Highway B and ended at the junction of Highway 34 and FF Highway. Most of the structural damage was in Patterson at the junction of Highways 34 and FF.
A few trees were damaged by this cigar shaped tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance combined with a strong surface low pressure system moving across West Central Texas produced a significant squall line that moved through the entire San Angelo county warning area. This squall line was accompanied by 60 to 80 MPH winds which produced widespread damage, especially across the Big Country. Embedded within the squall line, were several Supercell thunderstorms which produced nine tornadoes within the San Angelo county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous manufactured homes were damaged or destroyed by a tornado around Lake Sweetwater.
A small tornado tore off some siding and part of the roof off a barn.

The tornado produced structural damage confined to the Claiborne Academy School gymnasium.  There were kids in the school at the time of the storm but there were no injuries. Trees were snapped off and blown over in spotty areas at the beginning and end of the tornado track.
A tornado was observed by several storm chasers and spotters touching down in an open field. No damage was reported.
A brief tornado touchdown was reported.

A weak tornado briefly touched down 3 miles west-southwest of West. As the tornado moved northeast it tore siding off a building, blew an antenna down, damaged a poorly constructed outbuilding and blew down several small trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A member of the general public photographed and reported several very weak landspouts that occurred just south of the Klamath Falls airport at the above time and date.  Three of them contacted the ground.  This person reported the incident to the weathercaster at a local TV station and he relayed the information to us.  These appear to be little more than glorified dust devils in the photographs, but it was a cool and mostly cloudy day and the person said they were connected to the clouds.No warnings were issued for these landspouts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: See below.

A mobile home was unroofed southeast of Italy and numerous barns and outbuildings were damaged.  A family was trapped in a collapsed mobile home in Avalon, and another mobile home was blown over.Southwest of Avalon a high tension tower was bent over.

Trees and storage buildings were damaged south and southeast of Bardwell.  In the south part of Ennis, a mobile home was unroofed and several 18 wheelers were blown over. A 3 year old 3,000 sq ft house was destroyed.  A warehouse/office building along Interstate 45 had most of it's roof removed.  Another 18 wheeler on Interstate 45 was blown over.
A highly visible tornado was observed in open country. No damage was reported.
This was a brief tornado with no known damage.

A tornado touched down four miles south of Sharon and moved to the east-northeast. A car was blown off state highway 34, 3.8 miles south of Sharon, and a cow was killed by the tornado nearby. Otherwise no other damage is known to indicate the tornado's intensity. At times this tornado was multiple vortex.
Storm chasers observed a brief tornado in open country. No damage was reported.

A second thunderstorm developed to the southwest of the first tornadic storm. Spotters observed a tornado with this storm that also crossed state highway 34, a couple of miles south of the tornado produced by the first storm. This tornado also downed several cedar trees.
A brief tornado was observed in open country which produced no known damage.
A storm chaser observed a brief tornado in open country. No damage was reported.
Numerous storm chasers observed this short-lived tornado touchdown in open country. No damage was reported.
Many storm chasers observed a brief, narrow tornado in open country, with no known damage.

Several chasers reported a well-defined funnel cloud moving from near Thomas to near Fay. One storm chaser video taped a weak tornado touching down very briefly northwest of Thomas. No damage was reported.
Two funnel clouds developed south of Okarche with several chasers seeing one tornado touch down briefly. No known damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance combined with a strong surface low pressure system moving across West Central Texas produced a significant squall line that moved through the entire San Angelo county warning area. This squall line was accompanied by 60 to 80 MPH winds which produced widespread damage, especially across the Big Country. Embedded within the squall line, were several Supercell thunderstorms which produced nine tornadoes within the San Angelo county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado started near the Potosi community and moved to the northeast before crossing into western Callahan County.
A short lived tornado with estimated winds around 70 mph touched down near Sewanee and twisted and uprooted around 50 trees in a heavily wooded area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm formed over extreme southeast Lincoln County and then moved east through south central Chaves County producing a string of weak tornadoes and then collapsing with a burst of baseball size hail. A series of relatively brief and weak tornadoes were observed as the storm passed from about 24 miles southwest of Roswell to 6 miles south of Roswell. These intermittent tornadoes were located over open range or rural and unpopulated sections of Chaves County, but were observed from long distance by FAA controllers at the Roswell Airport and by Skywarn amateur radio spotters. The storm overturned one mobile home near the Midway community. A witness report conflicted with debris patterns so it was uncertain whether this damage was caused by straight line winds or a dissipating tornado. The occupant had abandoned the mobile home and sought safe shelter elsewhere after hearing one of the earlier tornado warnings.

An isolated thunderstorm formed over extreme southeast Lincoln County and then moved east through south central Chaves County producing a string of weak tornadoes and then collapsing with a burst of baseball size hail. A series of relatively brief and weak tornadoes were observed as the storm passed from about 24 miles southwest of Roswell to 6 miles south of Roswell. These intermittent tornadoes were located over open range or rural and unpopulated sections of Chaves County, but were observed from long distance by FAA controllers at the Roswell Airport and by Skywarn amateur radio spotters. The storm overturned one mobile home near the Midway community. A witness report conflicted with debris patterns so it was uncertain whether this damage was caused by straight line winds or a dissipating tornado. The occupant had abandoned the mobile home and sought safe shelter elsewhere after hearing one of the earlier tornado warnings.
