A series of relatively brief and weak tornadoes were observed as the storm passed from about 24 miles southwest of Roswell to 6 miles south of Roswell. These intermittent tornadoes were located over open range or rural and unpopulated sections of Chaves County, but were observed from long distance by FAA controllers at the Roswell Airport and by Skywarn amateur radio spotters. The storm overturned one mobile home near the Midway community. A witness report conflicted with debris patterns so it was uncertain whether this damage was caused by straight line winds or a dissipating tornado. The occupant had abandoned the mobile home and sought safe shelter elsewhere after hearing one of the earlier tornado warnings.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado moved from Washington County, Indiana into western Clark County in the vicinity of Borden. It briefly reached F2 intensity in the Borden area, blowing the roofs off several homes. The roof was blown off an elementary school while a graduation was in progress, but no injuries were reported. In all, the tornado destroyed or damaged 10 homes in the Borden area. The tornado continued moving east southeast across Clark County, lifting intermittently. Several witnesses spotted the tornado as it moved south of Charlestown. It caused some F1 damage in the Stacy Road and Bethany Road areas, before lifting southeast of Charlestown.

The tornado touched down initially in western Washington County, where it destroyed a home and a garage. It skipped across Washington County, with the next reported damage in the vicinity of Pekin. Several homes and farm buildings were damaged or destroyed there.  A total of nine homes were destroyed in Washington County, and 31 homes were damaged to some degree. The tornado then continued southeast and crossed into Clark County, Indiana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms moved through Manitowoc county on the morning of the 23rd as a low pressure system moved into southern Wisconsin, dragging a stationary front north as a warm front.   High winds from the storms tore the roof from a barn, snapped and uprooted trees and downed power lines.  A tornado touched down down briefly east of Reedsville, damaging shingles and siding on a house, and snapping trees and large branches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado touchdown near 146/128 interchange.
Brief tornado touchdown along Harrison Daviess county line. Tornado left Harrison county 1 mile south of Melbourne and entered Daviess county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst severe weather outbreaks in recent years struck south-central Nebraska the afternoon and evening of May 22. No less than 17 different tornadoes rolled across south-central Nebraska. Dozens of homes were damaged and a few completely destroyed. Over 250 center irrigation pivots were damaged or destroyed in south-central Nebraska alone. Large hail and strong straight-line winds of up to 80 mph also wreaked havoc on the region. Several million dollars in property damage was reported. Hundreds of power poles were snapped resulting in dozens of miles of downed electrical line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado traveled a 7 mile path in southeast Adams county and produced some damage, mainly to center pivot systems.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A west to east orientated frontal boundary lifted north through southeast Michigan during the afternoon hours of the 22nd. Multiple weak tornadoes occurred across the Tri-Cities and Thumb region. No injuries were reported with mainly minor damage. Consumers Energy reported that more than 235,000 customers were without power as a result of the May 21st and 22nd storms, the 10th highest total in Consumers Energy history. DTE Energy had 210,000 customers without power over the weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touchdown was reported near Beyer Road and M-46. Trees and wires were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of May 19th a thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in the Fancher Heights area of East Wenatchee. The tornado touched down over an open field and caused no damage. The parent thunderstorm also produced 3/4 inch diameter hail in East Wenatchee.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Burlington Northern employees reported a brief tornado in southern Ralls County. The train had stopped to allow another train to pass when a small tornado passed in front of the lead locomotive. Some trees were damaged in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 30 May 2004, a warm front was draped across far southern portions of Indiana in the morning, as part of an unseasonably strong cyclone centered in Minnesota.  This warm front began the day nearly stationary, taking 8 hours to move from Vincennes to Bloomington, then rocketing northward as the low pressure system quickly pushed off to the northeast late, dragging a cold front through the state during the overnight hours. All the necessary ingredients for a major severe weather outbreak were falling into place.  Morning upper-air observations showed very deep moisture and intense wind shear (wind change in speed and direction with respect to height) in the lower levels of the atmosphere.  Fairly clear skies during the course of the day contributed to moderately strong instability across much of Indiana.  Along and north of the warm front, winds backed to the east-southeast, further enhancing the wind shear.  This area of enhanced shear with the deep moisture and instability pooled along it would serve as the focus for the first two rounds of severe weather in the Indianapolis County Warning Area (CWA) on May 30th.The first wave of severe weather came in the early afternoon, as individual rotating thunderstorms, or supercells, formed just south of the warm front, crossing over the boundary soon after forming and moving into the area of enhanced shear.  These supercells began to show strong rotation soon after their formation, and produced several funnel reports and confirmed tornadoes near Spencer and Ellettsville.  Each of these tornadoes were rated F1 on the Fujita Scale of Tornado Intensity, a rating corresponding to the partial peeling of roofs and destruction of small outbuildings.Wave number two began in the late afternoon and continued into the early evening hours. Additional supercell development occurred further west along the warm front, in an area that had been receiving plenty of heating all day, maximizing instability in the very moist air mass. This wave of storms included a storm that produced tornadoes in Fountain and Tippecanoe counties, one of which was rated F2 near Dayton, just southeast of Lafayette, and a long-lived supercell that tracked along and just south of the I-70 corridor, producing tornadoes in Brazil, Little Point, Monrovia, just south of Plainfield, Camby, and Indianapolis.  Power flashes from the Camby tornado were visible from the front door of NWS Indianapolis.  The strongest of these tornadoes was the Indianapolis tornado, which briefly achieved F2 strength on the southeast side near Keystone Avenue between Raymond and Troy where there was significant damage to numerous homes, a nursing home and an elementary school. 26 nursing home inhabitants were treated at local hospitals for minor injuries, and the rest were relocated as the building was inhabitable. In addition to this tornado, the Monrovia tornado was rated F1.  All additional tornadoes from this particular supercell were rated F0, a rating corresponding to moderate tree damage and damage to outbuildings and signboards. There was also a lightning fatality in Veedersburg in Fountain County as a 24 year old male was struck while on a baseball field.The final wave of severe weather came in the late evening and early nighttime hours, and was mostly in the form of wind damage, although brief tornadoes did occur along the squall line that had formed near the Mississippi River and tracked eastward, accompanying the passage of the cold front, including tornadoes near Lake Monroe and Crothersville in south central Indiana, and Atlanta and Frankton in north central Indiana.  The tornado near Lake Monroe was rated F1, while all additional tornadoes were rated F0.To complicate the issue, the repeated rounds of heavy rain caused flooding problems across much of the area, with several flash flood warnings and urban/small stream flood advisories being issued during the evening and overnight hours.Fifteen total tornadoes touched down in central Indiana on May 30th, with damage estimates approaching $13,000,000 for central Indiana alone. In all, an additional eight tornadoes touched down in portions of Indiana that are served by neighboring NWS forecast offices, bringing the statewide total for the day to 23, four over the yearly average of 19.  This places the May 30th outbreak as the second largest outbreak in state history, behind the outbreak of 2 June 1990, and ahead of the "Super Outbreak" of 3-4 April 1974.  37 tornadoes touched down statewide in the 1990 outbreak, and 21 tornadoes touched down during the Super Outbreak, which was the largest outbreak of tornadoes in recorded history, with 148 tornadoes touching down across 13 states and southern Canada, killing 351 and injuring thousands.  Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F1 tornado skipped along for almost 8 and a half miles from near Freedom to Spencer. A few homes received significant damage about midway along the path of the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 30 May 2004, a warm front was draped across far southern portions of Indiana in the morning, as part of an unseasonably strong cyclone centered in Minnesota.  This warm front began the day nearly stationary, taking 8 hours to move from Vincennes to Bloomington, then rocketing northward as the low pressure system quickly pushed off to the northeast late, dragging a cold front through the state during the overnight hours. All the necessary ingredients for a major severe weather outbreak were falling into place.  Morning upper-air observations showed very deep moisture and intense wind shear (wind change in speed and direction with respect to height) in the lower levels of the atmosphere.  Fairly clear skies during the course of the day contributed to moderately strong instability across much of Indiana.  Along and north of the warm front, winds backed to the east-southeast, further enhancing the wind shear.  This area of enhanced shear with the deep moisture and instability pooled along it would serve as the focus for the first two rounds of severe weather in the Indianapolis County Warning Area (CWA) on May 30th.The first wave of severe weather came in the early afternoon, as individual rotating thunderstorms, or supercells, formed just south of the warm front, crossing over the boundary soon after forming and moving into the area of enhanced shear.  These supercells began to show strong rotation soon after their formation, and produced several funnel reports and confirmed tornadoes near Spencer and Ellettsville.  Each of these tornadoes were rated F1 on the Fujita Scale of Tornado Intensity, a rating corresponding to the partial peeling of roofs and destruction of small outbuildings.Wave number two began in the late afternoon and continued into the early evening hours. Additional supercell development occurred further west along the warm front, in an area that had been receiving plenty of heating all day, maximizing instability in the very moist air mass. This wave of storms included a storm that produced tornadoes in Fountain and Tippecanoe counties, one of which was rated F2 near Dayton, just southeast of Lafayette, and a long-lived supercell that tracked along and just south of the I-70 corridor, producing tornadoes in Brazil, Little Point, Monrovia, just south of Plainfield, Camby, and Indianapolis.  Power flashes from the Camby tornado were visible from the front door of NWS Indianapolis.  The strongest of these tornadoes was the Indianapolis tornado, which briefly achieved F2 strength on the southeast side near Keystone Avenue between Raymond and Troy where there was significant damage to numerous homes, a nursing home and an elementary school. 26 nursing home inhabitants were treated at local hospitals for minor injuries, and the rest were relocated as the building was inhabitable. In addition to this tornado, the Monrovia tornado was rated F1.  All additional tornadoes from this particular supercell were rated F0, a rating corresponding to moderate tree damage and damage to outbuildings and signboards. There was also a lightning fatality in Veedersburg in Fountain County as a 24 year old male was struck while on a baseball field.The final wave of severe weather came in the late evening and early nighttime hours, and was mostly in the form of wind damage, although brief tornadoes did occur along the squall line that had formed near the Mississippi River and tracked eastward, accompanying the passage of the cold front, including tornadoes near Lake Monroe and Crothersville in south central Indiana, and Atlanta and Frankton in north central Indiana.  The tornado near Lake Monroe was rated F1, while all additional tornadoes were rated F0.To complicate the issue, the repeated rounds of heavy rain caused flooding problems across much of the area, with several flash flood warnings and urban/small stream flood advisories being issued during the evening and overnight hours.Fifteen total tornadoes touched down in central Indiana on May 30th, with damage estimates approaching $13,000,000 for central Indiana alone. In all, an additional eight tornadoes touched down in portions of Indiana that are served by neighboring NWS forecast offices, bringing the statewide total for the day to 23, four over the yearly average of 19.  This places the May 30th outbreak as the second largest outbreak in state history, behind the outbreak of 2 June 1990, and ahead of the "Super Outbreak" of 3-4 April 1974.  37 tornadoes touched down statewide in the 1990 outbreak, and 21 tornadoes touched down during the Super Outbreak, which was the largest outbreak of tornadoes in recorded history, with 148 tornadoes touching down across 13 states and southern Canada, killing 351 and injuring thousands.  Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State police reported a brief weak tornado touchdown in a field near Veedersburg.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F1 tornado caused significant damage to a cabin northeast of Ellettsville. Most of the path was along a wooded area with numerous trees felled.
This tornado tracked over open country.
A half-mile damage path occurred near Six Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst severe weather outbreaks in recent years struck south-central Nebraska the afternoon and evening of May 22. No less than 17 different tornadoes rolled across south-central Nebraska. Dozens of homes were damaged and a few completely destroyed. Over 250 center irrigation pivots were damaged or destroyed in south-central Nebraska alone. Large hail and strong straight-line winds of up to 80 mph also wreaked havoc on the region. Several million dollars in property damage was reported. Hundreds of power poles were snapped resulting in dozens of miles of downed electrical line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado was reported north of Orleans

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was located over the Tri-Cities and Thumb region during the early evening hours of the 23rd.Numerous severe thunderstorms over southeast Michigan produced mostly wind damage. However, there were a few hail reports and weak tornadoes, mainly along the I-69 corridor. Total damage across southeast Michigan during May 21-23 from severe storms was estimated near 13 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down near Duffield and Mt. Morris Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A west to east orientated frontal boundary lifted north through southeast Michigan during the afternoon hours of the 22nd. Multiple weak tornadoes occurred across the Tri-Cities and Thumb region. No injuries were reported with mainly minor damage. Consumers Energy reported that more than 235,000 customers were without power as a result of the May 21st and 22nd storms, the 10th highest total in Consumers Energy history. DTE Energy had 210,000 customers without power over the weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1 mile west of Fostoria. Numerous trees were blown down. Two homes also sustained roof damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in southern Shelby county around 9 miles south southeast of Harlan.  The tornado tracked into Pottawattamie county on the west side of Walnut.  There it strengthened to a f1 category, damaging buildings and roofs in town.  One garage was destroyed and a radio tower was overturned. A grain bin was destroyed and carried for about a half of a mile. The tornado lifted around 4 miles south southeast of Walnut.  The total path length was around 8 miles and it was on the ground for about 11 minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were blown down.
F1 tornado moved out of Madison County in Alabama and into southeast Lincoln County in Tennessee. The tornado snapped numerous trees and power poles with some of the debris falling on structures.
F1 tornado continued out of Lincoln County and into southwest Franklin County. The tornado snapped numerous trees and power lines as it passed just south of Huntland.

A F1 tornado touched down just east of Lynchburg and moved eastward out of Moore county and into Franklin county toward Tims Ford Lake. The tornado remained in rural areas with the damage confined to trees that were snapped and uprooted.

A F1 tornado moved eastward out of Moore County across parts of Tims Ford Lake and into northwest Franklin County before dissipating near Center Grove.  While most of the damage was confined to trees, a few boats were overturned in Tims Ford Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a strong upper level disturbance and cold front moving across the area produced a widespread severe weather event across much of west central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a brief tornado touch down reported just outside the community of Neinda. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a strong upper level disturbance and cold front moving across the area produced a widespread severe weather event across much of west central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser photographed a brief tornado in a rural area of central Throckmorton county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A west to east orientated frontal boundary lifted north through southeast Michigan during the afternoon hours of the 22nd. Multiple weak tornadoes occurred across the Tri-Cities and Thumb region. No injuries were reported with mainly minor damage. Consumers Energy reported that more than 235,000 customers were without power as a result of the May 21st and 22nd storms, the 10th highest total in Consumers Energy history. DTE Energy had 210,000 customers without power over the weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down near M-52 and Garrison Roads. A 4 foot diameter tree was snapped.

This F2 tornado was consistently on the ground from one mile south of Stanberry  east-northeastthrough Albany. Muliple vortices were noticed on chaser video. Extensive damage was observed in Albany. Three homes were destroyed. There were 34 buildings with major damage and 70 buildings had minor damage.
Brief tornado touchdown documented by storm chasers.
Brief tornado touchdown at Highway 136 and CC.
This F1 tornado damaged one barn and crops and was the first tornado of the day from this supercell thunderstorm.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field.  No damage or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down in Scott County two miles south of Clinchport around 545 pm EDT and traveled one half mile east.  The tornado was 50 yards wide and the only damage observed was to trees and some minor roof damage along CR 627.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The first of 5 tornadoes that occurred with a bow echo storm which moved northeast across eastern Washington County formed 1.5 miles west of Dubois Illinois at 6:24 pm CDT and traveled northeast across U.S. Highway 51. Outbuildings from two farmsteads west of U.S. Highway 5 1 sustained minor damage.  The tornado then cut through an area of large trees and traveled north-northeast to 1 mile northwest of Radom before it dissipated. Overall path length was 4.5 miles long and damage width varied from 40 to 70 yards.  Damage intensity with the first tornado was rated F1.

At 404 pm cdt a tornado developed  on the north of Coweta near the intersection of Highway 51 and 127th Street South.  The tornado traveled south southeast into Coweta before dissipating at 410 pm cdt just before reaching Highway 51 near 305th East Avenue.  The tornado damaged the roofs of a number of homes and downed trees and power lines.

The tornado initially touched down 6 miles west southwest of Winchester then traveled to the northeast causing minor tree damage.  Two miles southwest of Winchester it destroyed a mobile home causing 1 fatality.  The two occupants of the mobile home were thrown from the home.  The husband only sustained minor injuries.  As the tornado went through Winchester it weakened in intensity causing minor to moderate damage to the roofs of several homes, destroyed some sheds and blew down numerous trees.

A small tornado touched down in the southwest section of Jacksonville near the point where Route 67 turns north.  As it traveled to the northeast it quickly intensified to F2 strength destroying a furniture store, house and church and caused major damage to a motel.  One occupant of the motel sustained minor injuries.  The tornado then quickly weakened causing minor damage to several more homes and businesses before lifting and dissipating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms rumbled across south-central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours.  These storms produced hail, strong winds and a few tornadoes.  The storms started out in Gosper county and moved northeast.  There were several reports of funnel clouds in eastern Gosper county.  As the storms continued into Dawson and Buffalo counties, storm chasers continued to report funnels and hail.  The first tornado set down in southeast Sherman county near Rockville and was observed for a few minutes.  The next twister was in southwest Howard county near Farwell.  Another tornado was reported by a sheriff's deputy near the junction of Nebraska highways 92 and 11.  These tornadoes were in open county and caused little in the way of damage.  The town of Elba in Howard county has pummeled by large hail for period of time.  Broken windows and trees stripped of leaves were common throughout the small community.  The most destructive tornado occurred near the village of Cushing.  The tornado set down on a farm west of town and damaged several outbuildings and threw irrigation pipe across a field.  The tornado then cut a path across the south end of town, again damaging several outbuildings and some minor damage to a home.  The tornado dissipated just southeast of town.  Other storms south of these produced strong winds from Grand Island to near Hebron.  Trees and power poles were damaged from the strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado set down west of Cushing and traveled eastward.  It damaged or destroyed a few outbuildings and damaged one home.
A brief touchdown was reported.
A brief touchdown was reported.
Multiple funnels periodically touched the ground.
A tornado blew down several evergreens, tore a barn door off, and knocked a grain auger into a grain bin.
A brief tornado caused no reported damage.
A tornado destroyed a small shed.
Local law enforcement reported a brief tornado touchdown along Stolletown Road. No damage was reported.
A tornado reportedly touched down 2 miles northeast of La Center and uprooted a 1 1/2 foot diameter tree and tore off part of a barn roof.

A tornado moved from the west northwest of Depew to the north northeast of Depew.  At its strongest it produced F3 damage.  The F3 rating was based on a 20 foot section of a concrete anchored iron pipe cattle gate being removed from the ground and displaced 30 feet.  The gate was anchored by 3 posts.  All of the posts were set in 24 inches of concrete.  Another tornado formed near and just after this tornado dissipated.  The two tornadoes formed a nearly continuous damage path.  The damage produced by the two tornadoes in western Creek County included 5 mobile homes destroyed, 2 houses destroyed, and 4 houses with significant roof damage.  The path of the second tornado is described in a subsequent entry.
A weak tornado was spotted with no damage reported.
A weak tornado caused tree damage just south of Highway 61 northwest of Hannibal.
An off duty NWS employee reported a brief tornado on the east side of Carlyle Lake.
A small tornado touched down but did no damage.

This is the tornado mentioned in the previous entry. It formed near and just after the first tornado and traveled mainly through open territory.  However, some of the structural damage that was mentioned earlier occurred along its path.
A weak tornado touched down briefly just southeast of Bath, causing no damage.
The same storm that produced the F0 tornado for 5 minutes southeast of Bath produced a second tornado 7 miles north of Bath about 10 minutes later.  This tornado was also weak and produced no damage.

A tornado briefly touched down on a storage building damaging the roof.  A section of the roof was lifted off and landed on a car in the parking lot, damaging the unoccupied car.  The tornado then quickly lifted and dissipated.  No injuries were reported.
Brief tornado touchdown north of Grant City.

A tornado touched down southeast of Wayne causing damage to a house and destroying or severely damaging a barn and 6 outbuildings, along with much of the farm equipment. The debris was strewn for 3 miles downwind.

A tornado was on the ground for around 1.5 miles just west through north of Murdock. The tornado knocked down many trees and power lines in the area, and several outbuildings were destroyed.  This tornado was from the same supercell complex that spawned the long tracked f4 tornado that did extensive damage in the Hallam area.
Several large trees were blown down.

In addition to this tornado, the Monrovia tornado was rated F1. There was also a lightning fatality in Veedersburg in Fountain County as a 24 year old male was struck while on a baseball field.The final wave of severe weather came in the late evening and early nighttime hours, and was mostly in the form of wind damage, although brief tornadoes did occur along the squall line that had formed near the Mississippi River and tracked eastward, accompanying the passage of the cold front, including tornadoes near Lake Monroe and Crothersville in south central Indiana, and Atlanta and Frankton in north central Indiana.  The tornado near Lake Monroe was rated F1, while all additional tornadoes were rated F0.To complicate the issue, the repeated rounds of heavy rain caused flooding problems across much of the area, with several flash flood warnings and urban/small stream flood advisories being issued during the evening and overnight hours.Fifteen total tornadoes touched down in central Indiana on May 30th, with damage estimates approaching $13,000,000 for central Indiana alone. In all, an additional eight tornadoes touched down in portions of Indiana that are served by neighboring NWS forecast offices, bringing the statewide total for the day to 23, four over the yearly average of 19.  This places the May 30th outbreak as the second largest outbreak in state history, behind the outbreak of 2 June 1990, and ahead of the "Super Outbreak" of 3-4 April 1974.  37 tornadoes touched down statewide in the 1990 outbreak, and 21 tornadoes touched down during the Super Outbreak, which was the largest outbreak of tornadoes in recorded history, with 148 tornadoes touching down across 13 states and southern Canada, killing 351 and injuring thousands.  Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down briefly just east and northeast of Joppa. Report was from a National Weather Service storm survey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 30 May 2004, a warm front was draped across far southern portions of Indiana in the morning, as part of an unseasonably strong cyclone centered in Minnesota.  This warm front began the day nearly stationary, taking 8 hours to move from Vincennes to Bloomington, then rocketing northward as the low pressure system quickly pushed off to the northeast late, dragging a cold front through the state during the overnight hours. All the necessary ingredients for a major severe weather outbreak were falling into place.  Morning upper-air observations showed very deep moisture and intense wind shear (wind change in speed and direction with respect to height) in the lower levels of the atmosphere.  Fairly clear skies during the course of the day contributed to moderately strong instability across much of Indiana.  Along and north of the warm front, winds backed to the east-southeast, further enhancing the wind shear.  This area of enhanced shear with the deep moisture and instability pooled along it would serve as the focus for the first two rounds of severe weather in the Indianapolis County Warning Area (CWA) on May 30th.The first wave of severe weather came in the early afternoon, as individual rotating thunderstorms, or supercells, formed just south of the warm front, crossing over the boundary soon after forming and moving into the area of enhanced shear.  These supercells began to show strong rotation soon after their formation, and produced several funnel reports and confirmed tornadoes near Spencer and Ellettsville.  Each of these tornadoes were rated F1 on the Fujita Scale of Tornado Intensity, a rating corresponding to the partial peeling of roofs and destruction of small outbuildings.Wave number two began in the late afternoon and continued into the early evening hours. Additional supercell development occurred further west along the warm front, in an area that had been receiving plenty of heating all day, maximizing instability in the very moist air mass. This wave of storms included a storm that produced tornadoes in Fountain and Tippecanoe counties, one of which was rated F2 near Dayton, just southeast of Lafayette, and a long-lived supercell that tracked along and just south of the I-70 corridor, producing tornadoes in Brazil, Little Point, Monrovia, just south of Plainfield, Camby, and Indianapolis.  Power flashes from the Camby tornado were visible from the front door of NWS Indianapolis.  The strongest of these tornadoes was the Indianapolis tornado, which briefly achieved F2 strength on the southeast side near Keystone Avenue between Raymond and Troy where there was significant damage to numerous homes, a nursing home and an elementary school. 26 nursing home inhabitants were treated at local hospitals for minor injuries, and the rest were relocated as the building was inhabitable. In addition to this tornado, the Monrovia tornado was rated F1.  All additional tornadoes from this particular supercell were rated F0, a rating corresponding to moderate tree damage and damage to outbuildings and signboards. There was also a lightning fatality in Veedersburg in Fountain County as a 24 year old male was struck while on a baseball field.The final wave of severe weather came in the late evening and early nighttime hours, and was mostly in the form of wind damage, although brief tornadoes did occur along the squall line that had formed near the Mississippi River and tracked eastward, accompanying the passage of the cold front, including tornadoes near Lake Monroe and Crothersville in south central Indiana, and Atlanta and Frankton in north central Indiana.  The tornado near Lake Monroe was rated F1, while all additional tornadoes were rated F0.To complicate the issue, the repeated rounds of heavy rain caused flooding problems across much of the area, with several flash flood warnings and urban/small stream flood advisories being issued during the evening and overnight hours.Fifteen total tornadoes touched down in central Indiana on May 30th, with damage estimates approaching $13,000,000 for central Indiana alone. In all, an additional eight tornadoes touched down in portions of Indiana that are served by neighboring NWS forecast offices, bringing the statewide total for the day to 23, four over the yearly average of 19.  This places the May 30th outbreak as the second largest outbreak in state history, behind the outbreak of 2 June 1990, and ahead of the "Super Outbreak" of 3-4 April 1974.  37 tornadoes touched down statewide in the 1990 outbreak, and 21 tornadoes touched down during the Super Outbreak, which was the largest outbreak of tornadoes in recorded history, with 148 tornadoes touching down across 13 states and southern Canada, killing 351 and injuring thousands.  Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down just southwest of Friendswood in Southwestern Hendricks County and traveled 4.1 miles northeast to just north of West Newton in Marion County per National Weather Service storm survey.

Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down just southwest of Friendswood in southwest Hendricks County and moved 4.1 miles northeast to just north of West Newton in Marion County per National Weather Service storm survey.
A tornado touched down briefly at a farm and damaged a barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow from earlier thunderstorms over southeast Texas interacted with a sea breeze boundary and very moist and unstable atmosphere during the afternoon hours of the 13th.  Strong to severe thunderstorms erupted by late afternoon and early evening from Cotulla to George West to Victoria, persisting for several hours and training over several locations producing flooding rainfall.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a line and pushed offshore during the early morning hours of the 14th.  Extensive flooding crippled the southern half of Bee county, where radar estimated up to 10 to 12 inches of rainfall may have fallen.  Virtually all roads througout the southern half of the Bee county were impassible. Several residents were reported to have been rescued.  Below are selected rainfall totals for this event during the afternoon of the 13th and early morning hours of the 14th from ASOS, RAWS, Cooperative Observer and media sites....Victoria Crossroads Area...Station.............................. Amouts (inches)Coleto Creek...................... 2.59Victoria Airport................... 4.50 (3.63 new daily record for the 13th)Victoria Fire Station............ 3.30...Coastal Bend Area...Station.............................. Amouts (inches)Aransas Wildlife Refuge..... 5.89Bishop............................... 2.59Beeville............................. 1.68Corpus Christi Intl Arpt...... 2.78 (2.43 new daily record for the 13th)Kingsville.......................... 2.67N.A.S. Corpus Christi....... 4.29Refugio 2 NW................... 5.15Rockport........................... 4.82Sinton.............................. 3.60Tynan (1 NE)................... 9.35 (unoffical)...Media Reports...Station............................. Amouts (inches)Beeville 4 S...................... 7.20Ingleside On-The-Bay....... 3.80CC Airline & McArdle...... 5.10
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported brief tornado over open county.  No damage resulted.
The tornado was near the Grand Forks-Nelson county line.
The tornado was reported by GFAFB personnel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms rumbled across south-central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours.  These storms produced hail, strong winds and a few tornadoes.  The storms started out in Gosper county and moved northeast.  There were several reports of funnel clouds in eastern Gosper county.  As the storms continued into Dawson and Buffalo counties, storm chasers continued to report funnels and hail.  The first tornado set down in southeast Sherman county near Rockville and was observed for a few minutes.  The next twister was in southwest Howard county near Farwell.  Another tornado was reported by a sheriff's deputy near the junction of Nebraska highways 92 and 11.  These tornadoes were in open county and caused little in the way of damage.  The town of Elba in Howard county has pummeled by large hail for period of time.  Broken windows and trees stripped of leaves were common throughout the small community.  The most destructive tornado occurred near the village of Cushing.  The tornado set down on a farm west of town and damaged several outbuildings and threw irrigation pipe across a field.  The tornado then cut a path across the south end of town, again damaging several outbuildings and some minor damage to a home.  The tornado dissipated just southeast of town.  Other storms south of these produced strong winds from Grand Island to near Hebron.  Trees and power poles were damaged from the strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Short lived tornado observed by many chasers.  It remained in open country west of Farwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in southern Shelby county around 9 miles south southeast of Harlan.  The tornado tracked into Pottawattamie county on the west side of Walnut.  There it strengthened to a f1 category, damaging buildings and roofs in town.  One garage was destroyed and a radio tower was overturned. A grain bin was destroyed and carried for about a half of a mile. The tornado lifted around 4 miles south southeast of Walnut.  The total path length was around 8 miles and it was on the ground for about 11 minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado uprooted large trees and downed transmission towers from around Nehawka to near Union.  Two houses sustained major damage and "heavy damage" was reported to 30 other houses.  Some of the damage could have also been caused by straight line winds that occurred across parts of the area shortly before the reported time of the tornado.  The strong winds also knocked power out across most of Union.  The track of the tornado was around 4 miles long and was spawned from the same supercell complex that produced the long tracked f4 tornado earlier which caused extensive damage in the Hallam area.

This tornado damaged cabins and homes and downed trees near the Lake Waconda area by Murray.  The tornado was on the ground for about 1 mile, and it was produced from the same supercell complex that spawned 2 earlier tornadoes in Cass county and also the long tracked f4 tornado that caused extensive damage in the Hallam area.
A small tornado touched down but did no damage.
A small tornado touched down but did no damage.

Shortly after the severe winds and hail, the first and most powerful of several tornadoes struck.  It was observed by the Val Verde County Emergency Manager as it touched down near 640 pm south of Amistad Lake along Holdup Pass, approximately one mile south of US 90.  The tornado, rated F1on the Fujita scale, was about 100 yards wide.  It first moved eastward destroying the roof of a home and tossing the debris over one-quarter mile along its path.  Occupants of the home had found shelter in their interior closet and were uninjured in spite of considerable damage to the home and the surrounding area.  After tracking eastward for one mile the tornado turned 45 degrees to the right and tracked along mostly open country for almost 3 more miles.  Along the route it tore down power poles, leveled vegetation, damaged roofs and broke windows.  It then lifted and dissipated

The storm system continued to track to the east-southeast, moving over the city of Del Rio.  The Del Rio Emergency Manager reported being in his vehicle on F Street (US 90) as a small vortex formed just in front of him.  He reported that winds were quite strong, but that little moisture or debris was being blown around.  This would have been a small, developing F0 of minimal strength that he reported dissipated within a minute or so.  Based on the 40 mph movement of the storm, the time would have been around 6:47 pm.

The next tornado report was received from Laughlin Air Force Base, where the 709 pm observation noted a tornado.  This small F0 formed west of the Air Base and track eastward...but dissipated quickly as it approached the Base.  No damage was indicated.

Law enforcement officers witnessed a tornado touch down in a field along Clayburg Road in northern Weller Township.  This location is approximately three miles northwest of Olivesburg.  The tornado was only briefly on the ground and caused no damage.
A weak tornado touched down in a farm field on West Dewey Road. Winds were strong enough to throw an empty grain bin 200 feet.
A brief touchdown was reported.

Four trailer homes were blown over and a repair shop had extensive roof damage.  Trees and power lines were blown down, interrupting electrical service.  Two houses were also damaged.  Most people in the trailer homes drove away prior to the tornado, having been alerted to the impending danger.
A brief touchdown was reported.
A tornado touched down causing roof damage to a home and destroyed a barn.  Two other barns on nearby properties were extensively damaged.  Significant tree damage was also reported.
A small tornado touched down but did no damage.

The tornado started moving NE before becoming influenced by the outflow of the storm and darted back to the SE.  The tornado ripped the roof off one home and blew out two walls and a roof of another.  However, the tornado took dead aim on one home about 3.5 miles SE of Mulvane and completely removed it from it's foundation.  Two inhabitants were under the staircase in the basement and escaped with only minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow from earlier thunderstorms over southeast Texas interacted with a sea breeze boundary and very moist and unstable atmosphere during the afternoon hours of the 13th.  Strong to severe thunderstorms erupted by late afternoon and early evening from Cotulla to George West to Victoria, persisting for several hours and training over several locations producing flooding rainfall.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a line and pushed offshore during the early morning hours of the 14th.  Extensive flooding crippled the southern half of Bee county, where radar estimated up to 10 to 12 inches of rainfall may have fallen.  Virtually all roads througout the southern half of the Bee county were impassible. Several residents were reported to have been rescued. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement relayed tornado on ground near Highway 188 and Interstate 37.  Tornado was briefly on ground over open country and produced no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A west to east orientated frontal boundary lifted north through southeast Michigan during the afternoon hours of the 22nd. Multiple weak tornadoes occurred across the Tri-Cities and Thumb region. No injuries were reported with mainly minor damage. Consumers Energy reported that more than 235,000 customers were without power as a result of the May 21st and 22nd storms, the 10th highest total in Consumers Energy history. DTE Energy had 210,000 customers without power over the weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado blew apart 2 barns along Richmondville road near Burgess and Hunt Roads.

The tornado touched down about half a mile west of Fondulac dam.  It traveled down Coventry Lane for about a quarter of a mile before lifting and dissipating.  The damage was mainly to large trees, with a number of them falling on homes.  Two homes had their roofs lifted off, with several others having minor roof damage.  No injuries were reported.

Indiana State Police reported a tornado on the ground along Interstate 64 south of Georgetown. The tornado was on the ground intermittently for nearly four miles, until reaching the Edwardsville area. It uprooted some very large trees near Edwardsville, just east of Highway 62. There was no structural damage to buildings along the highway.

A tornado touched down near Taswell in northwest Crawford County. The tornado passed north of English, then reached it's maximum intensity as it reached the town of Marengo. Newspaper reports indicate that 50 to 60 homes in Marengo were destroyed, and another 100 were damaged. Approximately 80 percent of the buildings in Marengo received some degree of damage from the tornado. The tornado's last contact with the ground was north of Milltown in extreme northeast Crawford County. The tornado exhibited multiple vortices along it's track, and occasionally lifted off the ground.

The tornado was first spotted southwest of Salem in the Mill Creek Flats area off State Road 56. It destroyed a barn and some other outbuildings on Beck's Mill Road west of Salem. It lifted as it passed the city of Salem, then touched down again intermittently east of Salem. The tornado destroyed another barn on Walker Road east of Salem. The eastern extent of the tornado path and the ending time of the event are estimated.

A tornado touched down south of Topeka and moved to the eastnortheast for about a mile before lifting. A building and a shed were damaged. Power lines were downed and an unoccupied vehicle was rolled over.
A tornado touched down briefly near Harveyville.
A tornado touched down briefly in open country.
A tornado touched down briefly in open country.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread damaging winds raked all of southern Illinois. The storms were in the form of short lines or bows as they moved through Jefferson, Perry, and Jackson Counties, including Mount Vernon and Carbondale. A couple of tornadoes were spawned in those areas. As the storms moved east, they evolved into an intense squall line, producing widespread damaging gusts around 60 MPH with isolated higher gusts to 90 MPH. Numerous trees were blown down in nearly every county. Some of the trees fell on roads and power lines. In Wayne County, trees and utility poles were down in Sims, but the northwest part of the county from Orchardville to Johnsonville was hardest hit with utility damage. In Hamilton County, the whole city of Mcleansboro was without power after numerous trees fell. Several of the trees landed on houses, causing severe damage to at least one house. Trees fell on vehicles in Mount Carmel, where gusts were reported to 68 MPH. At least two occupied vehicles were struck by falling trees, one on Route 34 north of Harrisburg, and another north of Old Shawneetown. In both cases, the occupants were freed by rescue workers without being injured. In Harrisburg, trees fell on several houses and vehicles, and a radio tower used for fire dispatch operations was blown down. Two roofs were blown off of houses in Raleigh, just north of Harrisburg. A tree fell on a house in Thebes, near the Mississippi River in Alexander County. The most intense winds (estimated near 90 MPH) occurred in Massac County about 5 miles west of Round Knob, where a house lost portions of its roof and attic. At least 10 to 15 trees were reported down in Massac County. The storms produced very heavy rain that caused street flooding. The U.S. Highway 51 overpass on the north side of Cairo was blocked by high water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From Washington County, the tornado entered western Jefferson County about 5 miles south of where Interstate 64 crosses the county line, then moved northeast across the interstate near the Woodlawn exit. A semi was blown off the interstate near the exit. The tornado passed just south of Dix, then lifted north of Texico, less than 2 miles from the Marion County line. Damage in this very rural area consisted of numerous trees down and destroyed sheds and barns. About two dozen houses sustained damage, mostly due to trees falling on them. Many trees were on power lines, and power poles were snapped. The damage path was not continuous. The tornado was rated F-1 for just a brief portion of its track, where maximum winds were estimated near 110 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved southeast from the northwest Texas panhandle during the early evening hours into the central Texas panhandle. Damaging downburst winds and a couple of tornadoes occurred over the northwest Texas panhandle while large hail and high winds occurred across the central Texas panhandle. No injuries were reported from the severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down over open country approximately one mile south-southwest of where the derailed trains cars occurred. The tornado path length and width were measured as a damage survey was made on the tornado. No injuries were reported from the tornado. The tornado did cause minor damage to barns and equipment at a nearby farm.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field.  No damage or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few supercell thunderstorms tracked across western Kentucky during the early afternoon. Each thunderstorm showed distinct rotation and produced at least one tornado. The first tornadic storm developed just west of Paducah, and continued northeast across Livingston and Crittenden Counties before weakening. This storm produced only one confirmed tornado, which was at West Paducah. A second thunderstorm developed strong rotation between Princeton and Madisonville, then moved east, parallel to and a few miles north of the Western Kentucky Parkway. This storm produced the strongest tornado of the day, from Hopkins County into extreme western Muhlenberg County. A funnel cloud accompanied the storm across the rest of Muhlenberg County. A third strongly rotating storm moved across Christian and Todd Counties, and another moved south and east of Owensboro.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was observed from the National Weather Service office at Barkley Regional Airport in West Paducah. The tornado first touched down about a mile east of the airport and remained on the ground for  a mile or two. Near the start of the tornado track, a mobile home was blown four feet off its foundation, and part of its roof was torn off. The underpinning of two or three other mobile homes was damaged. A 10 foot by 10 foot storage shed was flattened. On old Highway 60, a tree fell on a house. Peak winds were estimated at 70 MPH.
Tornado crossed briefly into Harrison county near Melbourne.
Tornado crossed into Dekalb county near Osborn.
Brief tornado touchdown noted by storm chasers.

Large F4 tornado touched down 2 miles south of Weatherby and moved east northeast. The tornado killed 3 persons near Weatherby. The 80 and 60 year old fatalities occurred in a destroyed frame house. Two mobile homes were destroyed with one having the 54 year old fatality. The tornado crossed into Daviess county 4 miles east of Weatherby.
Brief satellite tornado  touchdown.
Tornado crossed over into Mercer county 4 miles wnw of Spickard.
Large F4 tornado crossed into Harrison county from Daviess county 5 miles south of Bethany over rural land and then dissipated.
This tornado briefly had circulation on the ground but was a funnel for about five minutes.  There was no damage.
This tornado completely destroyed a mobile home at the Cat House Recreation area northeast of Shields.  Trees in the area were also heavily damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through southeast Michigan during the late afternoon and early evening hours of the 14th, producing low-topped supercells north of M-59.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado caused damage along Trinklein, Stroebel, Hart, Miller, and Weigel roads in James Township. Damage was also reported along Center Road near Camelot Place Apartments in Saginaw Township.A National Weather Service storm survey determined winds reached up to 90 mph. Numerous trees and power lines were down.
A weak tornado briefly touched down and toppled trees and power lines.  Reported by the Geneva County EMA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms with widespread damaging winds moved east from southern Illinois, passing across Union, Henderson, and Daviess Counties. A series of intense downbursts with peak winds up to 120 MPH struck northern Daviess County. The severe damage was concentrated in a 5-mile wide path from Stanley through Owensboro to Yelvington. Approximately 40 to 50 houses received major damage, mostly due to trees falling on them. Another 40 to 50 homes received minor damage. Several barns and garages were destroyed. A house roof was blown off. Hundreds of downed trees, power lines, and power poles blocked numerous roads. A woman was trapped in her vehicle when a tree fell on it. An irrigation rig was overturned in the Stanley area, and at least one trailer was blown off its foundation. Debris and even a whole building blocked roads in the Stanley area of Daviess County. Damage in Union and Henderson Counties consisted of widespread tree damage. Trees were down across many primary roads, including the Pennyrile Parkway and U.S. Highways 41 and 60. A National Weather Service damage survey estimated peak winds near Geneva in Henderson County were near 75 MPH. At Geneva, numerous trees were down, a sun room was blown off a house, and there was minor structural damage such as broken windows and shingles off roofs. One large tree limb fell through the wall of a house. A survey of the damage in eastern Henderson County revealed a very short-track tornado near Spottsville. In Union County, many trees were down in Uniontown and Morganfield, and some power poles were snapped off. Some roof damage occurred at a shopping center on Highway 60 West near Morganfield, as well as two job corps center buildings in the same area. In the same location about a mile west of Morganfield, 50 to 75 trees were down. A garage was damaged in Uniontown. A National Weather Service damage survey indicated peak winds were near 75 MPH at Uniontown. The vast majority of significant damage was in the northern half of Union, Henderson, and Daviess Counties. Several trees were blown down in extreme northern Mclean County at Beech Grove.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A double wide mobile home was shoved 10 feet off its base. A 12-by-16 foot wooden shed was destroyed, killing 26 baby chicks. Several trees on the property were blown down. Peak winds were estimated around 110 MPH.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field near the intersection of I-74 and US-51.  No damage or injuries were reported.

A F0 tornado moved into Pawnee County from Noble County.  Most of the path of the tornado in Pawnee County was over Sooner Lake.  Just before the tornado dissipated it reached land and damaged a few trees.

A F1 tornado occurred in rural Osage county to the north northeast of Prue.  Numerous half foot in diameter Oak limbs were broken.  A few whole trees and power poles were also downed.  Two houses in the path had slight damage.
Numerous trees uprooted. Storage buildings damaged.
A weak tornado was observed by Louisiana State Police and a National Weather Service employee in the northwest portion of Kenner. Several trees were blown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down at 330 am EDT near the intersection of Mitchell and Greenbrier Roads and moved east just north of Mitchell Road then near the intersections of Stone Reagan and Kincaid Roads.  It then moved across Hughes Lake Road before turning northeast and ending near the intersection of Bucks Pocket and Spring Place Road.  The path was generally 25 to 50 yards wide...however in a few locations it was as wide as 100 yards. The tornado damaged several structures and downed several trees along its path and was rated an F1 on the Fujita Scale.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief touchdown of a tornado was sighted by several trained spotters near the Platte River southwest of Schuyler.  The tornado touched down in open fields and apparently did little or no damage.

The tornado touched down 1.5 miles southeast of Eureka and traveled to the east northeast.  Three miles southwest of Secor it destroyed 2 farm buildings, a grain bin and a corn crib.  From there it blew down numerous trees, destroyed two old farm buildings, moved hay bales and threw a medium sized gas tank half a mile into a field.  The tornado then lifted 2 miles northeast of Secor.  No injuries were reported.
A tornado touched down and caused extensive damage to a barn.
A tornado touched down but did no damage.

An F0 tornado touched down just east of Virginia Drive and traveled east southeast across the southern part of Hueytown. The tornado crossed Hueytown Road and ended just west of Brookline Drive. At least 20 homes were damaged by falling trees and 6 homes suffered major damage. The tornado path was 1.7 miles long and 150 yards wide at its widest point. Thousands of electric customers were left without power for several hours after the storm.Begin: 33 26 35/87 00 35	End: 33 25 72/86 58 75

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced short lived tornado that sat down west of Logan and moved northeast.  The storm was followed by local spotters in the area.  It hit one farmstead, damaging outbuildings and trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cape Coral Fire Department reported a weak slow moving tornado that passed through the 2600 block of SW 31st Lane to the 3700 block of Oasis. Two lanais were destroyed, shingles were blown off several roofs, and a fence was blown down.
A small tornado downed some trees and power lines east of French Village in the Goose Creek Lake area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 30 May 2004, a warm front was draped across far southern portions of Indiana in the morning, as part of an unseasonably strong cyclone centered in Minnesota.  This warm front began the day nearly stationary, taking 8 hours to move from Vincennes to Bloomington, then rocketing northward as the low pressure system quickly pushed off to the northeast late, dragging a cold front through the state during the overnight hours. All the necessary ingredients for a major severe weather outbreak were falling into place.  Morning upper-air observations showed very deep moisture and intense wind shear (wind change in speed and direction with respect to height) in the lower levels of the atmosphere.  Fairly clear skies during the course of the day contributed to moderately strong instability across much of Indiana.  Along and north of the warm front, winds backed to the east-southeast, further enhancing the wind shear.  This area of enhanced shear with the deep moisture and instability pooled along it would serve as the focus for the first two rounds of severe weather in the Indianapolis County Warning Area (CWA) on May 30th.The first wave of severe weather came in the early afternoon, as individual rotating thunderstorms, or supercells, formed just south of the warm front, crossing over the boundary soon after forming and moving into the area of enhanced shear.  These supercells began to show strong rotation soon after their formation, and produced several funnel reports and confirmed tornadoes near Spencer and Ellettsville.  Each of these tornadoes were rated F1 on the Fujita Scale of Tornado Intensity, a rating corresponding to the partial peeling of roofs and destruction of small outbuildings.Wave number two began in the late afternoon and continued into the early evening hours. Additional supercell development occurred further west along the warm front, in an area that had been receiving plenty of heating all day, maximizing instability in the very moist air mass. This wave of storms included a storm that produced tornadoes in Fountain and Tippecanoe counties, one of which was rated F2 near Dayton, just southeast of Lafayette, and a long-lived supercell that tracked along and just south of the I-70 corridor, producing tornadoes in Brazil, Little Point, Monrovia, just south of Plainfield, Camby, and Indianapolis.  Power flashes from the Camby tornado were visible from the front door of NWS Indianapolis.  The strongest of these tornadoes was the Indianapolis tornado, which briefly achieved F2 strength on the southeast side near Keystone Avenue between Raymond and Troy where there was significant damage to numerous homes, a nursing home and an elementary school. 26 nursing home inhabitants were treated at local hospitals for minor injuries, and the rest were relocated as the building was inhabitable. In addition to this tornado, the Monrovia tornado was rated F1.  All additional tornadoes from this particular supercell were rated F0, a rating corresponding to moderate tree damage and damage to outbuildings and signboards. There was also a lightning fatality in Veedersburg in Fountain County as a 24 year old male was struck while on a baseball field.The final wave of severe weather came in the late evening and early nighttime hours, and was mostly in the form of wind damage, although brief tornadoes did occur along the squall line that had formed near the Mississippi River and tracked eastward, accompanying the passage of the cold front, including tornadoes near Lake Monroe and Crothersville in south central Indiana, and Atlanta and Frankton in north central Indiana.  The tornado near Lake Monroe was rated F1, while all additional tornadoes were rated F0.To complicate the issue, the repeated rounds of heavy rain caused flooding problems across much of the area, with several flash flood warnings and urban/small stream flood advisories being issued during the evening and overnight hours.Fifteen total tornadoes touched down in central Indiana on May 30th, with damage estimates approaching $13,000,000 for central Indiana alone. In all, an additional eight tornadoes touched down in portions of Indiana that are served by neighboring NWS forecast offices, bringing the statewide total for the day to 23, four over the yearly average of 19.  This places the May 30th outbreak as the second largest outbreak in state history, behind the outbreak of 2 June 1990, and ahead of the "Super Outbreak" of 3-4 April 1974.  37 tornadoes touched down statewide in the 1990 outbreak, and 21 tornadoes touched down during the Super Outbreak, which was the largest outbreak of tornadoes in recorded history, with 148 tornadoes touching down across 13 states and southern Canada, killing 351 and injuring thousands.  Nationwide, several more tornadoes were reported, along with nearly 200 reports of large hail and nearly 600 reports of wind damage.  Reports occurred all along the Mississippi, Ohio, and Tennessee Valleys, stretching from central Minnesota all the way to northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down in a corn field 3 miles west of Brazil. No property damage was reported. The report was from an amateur radio operator.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down near Little Point just south of Interstate 70. There was light damage to one barn roof top. The report was from an a National Weather Service storm survey.

A tornado apparently intermittently touched down from the eastern sections of town where it toppled an air-conditioning unit on top of Walmart onto an SUV parked below, to a farmstead 2 miles east southeast of town where it did extensive damage to farm outbuildings.  Power poles were also snapped off in this path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst severe weather outbreaks in recent years struck south-central Nebraska the afternoon and evening of May 22. No less than 17 different tornadoes rolled across south-central Nebraska. Dozens of homes were damaged and a few completely destroyed. Over 250 center irrigation pivots were damaged or destroyed in south-central Nebraska alone. Large hail and strong straight-line winds of up to 80 mph also wreaked havoc on the region. Several million dollars in property damage was reported. Hundreds of power poles were snapped resulting in dozens of miles of downed electrical line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado was reported in southeast Thayer county.  This was the final tornado of the day in south-central Nebraska.  Damage was limited to trees, power poles and center pivot irrigation systems.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst severe weather outbreaks in recent years struck south-central Nebraska the afternoon and evening of May 22. No less than 17 different tornadoes rolled across south-central Nebraska. Dozens of homes were damaged and a few completely destroyed. Over 250 center irrigation pivots were damaged or destroyed in south-central Nebraska alone. Large hail and strong straight-line winds of up to 80 mph also wreaked havoc on the region. Several million dollars in property damage was reported. Hundreds of power poles were snapped resulting in dozens of miles of downed electrical line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado traveled north from near Byron to just south of Deshler.  Fortunately the tornado remained in primarily unpopulated areas.
A tornado briefly touched down, uprooting and twisting numerous trees.  A fence was also destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornadic thunderstorm moved east across Franklin County. A long-lived rotating wall cloud was associated with the storm. A brief tornado was spawned, but all of the tree damage was associated with straight-line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touchdown was observed. No damage was reported.
Brief tornado touchdown along the Harrison and Daviess county line. Tornado entered Daviess county 10 miles north of Jamesport, and then dissipated.

Another tornado was produced by the storm which produced tornadoes earlier in the vicinity of Depew and Bristow. This tornado went to the west and north of Kellyville producing F1 damage to mainly trees and power poles.
A tornado destroyed a farm house and several other buildings on a farm.
The tornado mainly moved over open country and caused damage to trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over several hours across southern Cheyenne County Colorado along a surface boundary and moved into portions of west-central Kansas during the evening.  Several reports of tornadoes were received from storm spotters and law enforcement, including one tornado which toppled a windmill and pushed over numerous large trees. Strong thunderstorm winds also accompanied some of the thunderstorms with one downburst, associated with a strong rear-flank downdraft, removing a barn roof.  Hail reports between 1 and 3 inches in diameter were common with the storms during the late afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief touchdown over open fields observed by storm chaser. No known damage.

Hail reports between 1 and 3 inches in diameter were common with the storms during the late afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief touchdown over open fields observed by law enforcement. No known damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over several hours across southern Cheyenne County Colorado along a surface boundary and moved into portions of west-central Kansas during the evening.  Several reports of tornadoes were received from storm spotters and law enforcement, including one tornado which toppled a windmill and pushed over numerous large trees. Strong thunderstorm winds also accompanied some of the thunderstorms with one downburst, associated with a strong rear-flank downdraft, removing a barn roof.  Hail reports between 1 and 3 inches in diameter were common with the storms during the late afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees flattened and a windmill destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved southeast from the northwest Texas panhandle during the early evening hours into the central Texas panhandle. Damaging downburst winds and a couple of tornadoes occurred over the northwest Texas panhandle while large hail and high winds occurred across the central Texas panhandle. No injuries were reported from the severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado path length and width were estimated. The tornado remained over open country and caused no damage or injuries.
A weak tornado briefly touched down causing no damage in rural northern Hancock County.

Cowlitz county, Washington dispatch received several reports of a tornado that touched down on the Oregon side of the Columbia River, about 3 miles southeast of Rainier, crossed the river to the mouth of the Kalama River as a waterspout, and moved onshore on the Washington side as a tornado.
This weak tornado did not do any damage (nothing to hit)

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical airmass over the area produced widespread showers and a few thunderstorms. A couple of these weak storms were similar to mini-supercell thunderstorms, contained very little lightning, and produced brief tornadoes that caused some damage in central Oklahoma during the evening of June 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near Highway 66 west of Chandler, moved northeast, and lifted near Chandler Lake. This tornado damaged trees and power lines. Several roofs of homes were damaged along with several barns damaged or destroyed. A mobile home was destroyed near Chandler Lake before the tornado lifted. Several horses were injured and a cow and a horse were killed by debris in the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical airmass over the area produced widespread showers and a few thunderstorms. A couple of these weak storms were similar to mini-supercell thunderstorms, contained very little lightning, and produced brief tornadoes that caused some damage in central Oklahoma during the evening of June 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado affected the east side of Agra, near Highway 18, before moving north and dissipating in pasture land north of town. Three homes were damaged with the roof of one home lifted off. Several barns or outbuildings were damaged or destroyed. A double-wide trailer home also sustained roof damage. Many trees were damaged across town.
Tornado on the ground for 2-3 minutes. No known damage.  tornado close to intersection of CR54 and CR Z.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of severe weather affected parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin on June 23rd, with the second round featuring 8 tornadoes, large hail (up to golf-ball size), and powerful straight-line downburst winds.  A warm front moving north through the area resulted in favorable vertical wind shear to allow for supercell development.The 1st round of severe weather was due to a broken line of intense thunderstorms moving  across Walworth, Milwaukee, Racine and Kenosha counties.  Hail of up to 1 inch in diameter and torrential rainfall accompanied these storms before they moved over Lake Michigan and weakened.  The 2nd round of severe weather was dominated by 2 cyclic supercells - one moved east/southeast through Marquette, Green Lake, Fond du Lac, and Washington Counties, spinning up 5 separate tornadoes, dumping hail stones up to 3 inches in diameter, and hurricane-force downburst winds.  The large hail dented several vehicles.  Two of these were rated F3.  Refer to the individual tornado reports for more details.  A more southerly supercell tracked across extreme southern Sauk County and then made a partial right turn and headed southeast through Dane County, spinning up 2 tornadoes in the process, as well as large hail and downburst winds.  One powerful downburst wind in Madison (Dane Co.) blew equipment off the roof of a business at the Midvale Shopping Mall.  A semi southwest of Ft. Atkinson was blown over by straight-line wind gusts.  This southern supercell eventually spun up another tornado in south-central Jefferson County which moved into north-central Walworth County.  Refer to the individual tornado reports for more details.Both supercells had downbursts that generated large hail and powerful, hurricane-force winds north and south of their tracks.  Over all of Wisconsin, 16 tornadoes were documented on June 23rd, which is the 4th highest single-day total (record is 24 on May 8, 1988).  For south-central and southeast Wisconsin, the 8 tornadoes on June 23rd was tied for the 4th highest single-day total (record is 11 on May 8, 1988).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado is a continuation of the Jefferson County tornado.  Once it crossed the Jefferson/Walworth County line about 7 miles east-northeast of Whitewater, or about 1 mile west of CTH H, this tornado continued east-southeast and dissipated a short time later 3 miles north-northwest of La Grange.  Only tree damage was noted.  Average path width was about 100 yards.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field.  No damage or injuries were reported.

A tornado touched down 3 miles south southeast of Sidney and traveled to the southeast.  As it neared the intersection of county road 600 N and 2300 E it blew out several windows of a house and took the roof off of a barn.  Also, a chicken house was blown away.  Several power lines and tree limbs were blown down as well.  The tornado lifted and dissipated 4 miles north of Broadlands.  No injuries were reported.
A tornado touched down in a field and traveled to the southeast before lifting and dissipating.  No damage or injuries were reported.
A tornado briefly touched down in a field.  No damage or injuries were reported.

A more southerly supercell tracked across extreme southern Sauk County and then made a partial right turn and headed southeast through Dane County, spinning up 2 tornadoes in the process, as well as large hail and downburst winds.  One powerful downburst wind in Madison (Dane Co.) blew equipment off the roof of a business at the Midvale Shopping Mall.  A semi southwest of Ft. Refer to the individual tornado reports for more details.Both supercells had downbursts that generated large hail and powerful, hurricane-force winds north and south of their tracks.
